item.title: Japan | Member of nuclear regulator loses cell phone in China
item.description: Japanese authorities are investigating the loss of a professional cell phone, allegedly in China, which contained a confidential list of contacts from the Nuclear Regulation Authority, as confirmed to France-Presse by a person responsible for the organization. The incident, now made public, occurred at Shanghai airport, on November 3, when the employee was going through security control. The absence of the device was only noticed three days later, and, according to the Japanese press, it was not possible to block it or remotely erase its data as it was already out of reach. Although the cell phone did not contain direct access to nuclear data, according to the person in charge – who did not want to be identified – the list included names and contact details of members of the nuclear safety division of the regulatory authority – information that is not publicly accessible due to the sensitivity of the functions. The revelation comes in a context of growing tension between Beijing and Tokyo, after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi suggested in November that the country could intervene militarily in the event of Chinese aggression against Taiwan. At the same time, the operator Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) is seeking final approval to reactivate the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant, the largest in the world, closed after the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Japan has been gradually resuming nuclear energy, with 14 reactors already reactivated, within the framework of carbon neutrality targets by 2050 and increased demand for electricity due to artificial intelligence. The lost cellphone was reported to Japanese data protection authorities in November, according to the nuclear regulator. The case reignites concerns about information security in the nuclear energy sector at a delicate moment in Japanese energy policy.

item.title: Entertainment Zone | Government admits change of purpose
item.description: The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, admitted, in this Wednesday's debate in the Legislative Assembly (AL), that the Open Air Performance Zone, in Cotai, could host other types of community activities than just concerts. In response to an oral question from deputy Chan Lai Kei, the secretary stated that, after a year of experimental use, the intention is to “expand and reinforce the functions of the venue”, with “the spaces available between concerts being used to transform the venue into 3×3 basketball courts or spaces for family sporting activities”. The Zone will therefore be “a space open to citizens in order to increase flexibility and general benefits of use”. “Regarding the issue raised regarding the introduction of diverse events such as cultural and creative fairs, among others, the Government will maintain an open attitude in the evaluation process”, said the secretary.

item.title: Wynn, MGM and Melco announce bonuses for workers
item.description: Gaming concessionaires Wynn Resorts and MGM China announced a bonus equivalent to one month of work that will cover between 95 and 98 percent of workers. The information was released yesterday through press releases, after the Galaxy dealership announced a similar measure on Tuesday. As far as Wynn Macau is concerned, the bonus will cover 98 percent of the current 11,552 eligible employees, as “recognition of the exceptional contributions of all team members over the last year”. “We are truly grateful for the efforts and contributions of our team members over the past year and are pleased to announce a special grant in recognition of their hard work,” said Linda Chen, Vice President and CEO of Wynn Macau. “This year we celebrate the important milestone of our 20th anniversary in Macau — not only an achievement for Wynn, but also a testament to the dedication of every member of our team,” he added. General trends In the case of MGM, the bonus will cover 95 percent of workers, as “recognition for their dedication and contributions throughout 2025”. The amount will begin to be paid from the 21st of this month. “Reflecting on 2025, we are moving forward with a new chapter, continually optimizing our innovative products and service experiences, achieving steady progress in the development of our business – all thanks to the dedication and hard work of our team,” said Pansy Ho, president and CEO of MGM China in a statement. "Looking to the future, MGM will continue to enhance its strengths, with an unwavering focus on our guests. Guided by the philosophy of 'Originality + Innovation', we will remain dedicated to contributing to the positioning of Macau as a world-class tourism and leisure center, through the continuous introduction of more diverse tourism offerings", he stressed. Finally, Melco Resorts also announced a bonus for “eligible workers”, but the proportion of the workforce covered was not indicated. "The discretionary bonus payment recognizes the dedication and support of our colleagues over the past year. We sincerely appreciate their loyalty and commitment to consistently exceeding guest expectations, which together helps the company maintain and enhance its leadership position in the entertainment and hospitality industry," said Lawrence Ho, group president.

item.title: Macau Tower | Show celebrates Sino-Portuguese culture
item.description: A new theatrical show takes the stage tomorrow to explore how 500 years of contact between Portuguese and Chinese cultures gave Macau “a unique identity”. In the third edition of the “Macasaphis” series, the experimental theater group Frost Ice Snow Creative brings together music, theater, fashion, oral stories and stand-up comedy in the Macau Tower auditorium. The director, Sileas Ko Weng Si, told Lusa yesterday that, after a two-year break due to lack of funding, the group decided to return with the theme “Sino-Portuguese culture”. "Sino-Portuguese culture is everywhere, but we don't even realize it anymore. People often get confused, without understanding how it influences our lives", explained Sileas Ko. The first edition of “Macasahpis”, in 2022, had already been dedicated to particular elements of the region. “The presence of the Chinese and Portuguese languages, the historical monuments, the fact that we have the largest number of holidays in the world, both Buddhist and Catholic,” said Ko. Portuguese is one of the two official languages ​​of Macau, at least during the first 50 years of the new semi-autonomous Chinese region, according to the bilateral agreement that allowed the transition of administration in December 1999. The 2023 edition had as guests Tuna Macaense, a musical group from the Eurasian community, made up mainly of Portuguese descendants, who play songs in the Creole dialect, Patuá. But this time the group decided to go further and celebrate how Portuguese influence is also felt among the Chinese in Macau, the show's producer, Casta Lai Chit, told Lusa. “Maybe people still feel some shame in defining our culture and identity, because we are Chinese, but we are not the same as others”, explained Casta Lai, who has Portuguese nationality. “People are proud of Macau’s culture, but they have some shame in showing it”, lamented Sileas Ko. "Sino-Portuguese culture makes our city even more special. Without it, there would only be casinos", he added. Cultural power With an area of ​​just 33 square kilometers and less than 680,000 inhabitants, Macau “is a tiny fish” in the context of China, with a population of 1.4 billion, Casta Lai highlighted. “If it weren’t for Sino-Portuguese culture, Macau wouldn’t be important at all,” argued the producer. The show includes a part in which, in a humorous way, the population of Macau is treated as “an endangered species” and not just because the city has the lowest birth rate in the world, said Sileas Ko. Casta Lai warned that "maybe after 50 years the culture will be different. If that happens, maybe people will look around and miss what was lost."

item.title: IPIM | 13 plan applications received for international companies
item.description: The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute announced that it received 13 applications in the first two months of a program launched to attract international companies to the Macao SAR. More than 500 companies requested information about the support plan The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute (IPIM) revealed in a statement, released on Wednesday, that it had received 13 applications for the “Plan for Economic Development within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau”, opened in November last year. The entity added that it is analyzing applications to grant “financial support in accordance with budgetary capacity and public interest”. The Economic Development Plan within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau provides support of up to one million patacas. To receive maximum support, companies must follow certain requirements, such as establishing themselves in NAPE, Areia Preta, Iao Hon, San Kio area, Praia do Manduco, Fai Chi Kei, Doca do Lam Mau, Bairro de Tamagnini Barbosa or Ilha Verde. Furthermore, they must have a minimum area, as well as a certain number of full-time local employees. IPIM also highlighted that more than 500 companies requested information about the program, which was launched on November 1st. The plan lasts three years and has six application phases, the first of which runs until the end of January. At the end of November, the institute's president, Che Weng Keong, said in the Legislative Assembly that among the companies that requested more information about the plan were “brands from Portugal”. IPIM recalled that it “took the initiative” to contact entities in mainland China, Southeast Asia and Portuguese and Spanish speaking countries. Harvest fruits The program, which aims to “enrich the tourist charm of Macau and boost the community economy”, was presented in Lisbon and Porto, at the beginning of October, by IPIM officials, who then also held presentations in neighboring Spain, in Madrid and Barcelona. IPIM promised to continue publicizing the plan, including through participation in convention and exhibition events, “encouraging cooperation between Macau companies and foreign brands, including those from Portuguese-speaking countries”.

item.title: Game | Seaport forecasts 19% revenue growth in January
item.description: The basis of comparison helps, but Macau's main industry continues to expand month after month. The most recent report from Seaport Research Partners predicts that revenues will increase by 14 percent annually by March Financial services firm Seaport Research Partners predicts 19 percent annual gaming revenue growth in January, according to the institution's most recent report. At a quarterly level, revenues can increase by around 14 percent. “Our estimate for January points to an increase of 19 percent compared to the previous year (4 percent more compared to the previous month), with the growth rate helped by an easy comparison [compared to the 2025 value]”, can be read in the report by analyst Vitaly Umansky, cited by the GGR Asia portal. In January 2025, the game's gross revenue was 18.3 billion patacas, the lowest value of the entire year, which contributes to the highest relative growth. Despite the low basis for comparison, the 19 percent growth in revenue at the beginning of the year is seen by Umansky as a “solid” sign for the first quarter, in which gaming revenue is expected to expand by around 14 percent. It is recalled that in the first three months of 2025, revenue reached 57.7 billion patacas. “We estimate that the month started quite strong, possibly with revenues above 850 million patacas per day during the long weekend from January 1st to 4th”, the document states. Weakest December The forecast of 14 percent growth in the first quarter takes into account the fact that revenues slowed down in mid-December, which Seaport Research Partners believes is due to the fact that high rollers prefer to visit Macau to gamble between January and February. “We anticipate gross gaming revenues to grow more than 14 percent in the first quarter and seven percent in 2026,” Umansky said. “Growth in 2026 is supported by easy comparisons in the first half of the year and the continued easing of monetary flows and visa issuance”, he highlighted. Vitaly Umansky also said that if there is any unexpected increase in revenue in the mass market that the gaming industry's results could exceed the indicated forecast and that this increase would benefit concessionaires currently with greater capacity.

item.title: Inquiry | More than half of young people disappointed with salaries
item.description: A survey by the General Women's Association reveals that more than half of young people think salaries are below expectations and a third admit to a lack of professional experience. In terms of training, almost half of those surveyed would like to have more proficiency in languages The Macau General Women's Association yesterday presented a survey focused on youth employment. When looking for a job, or changing professional careers, more than 50 percent of young people surveyed indicated that salaries and benefits are below their expectations. Still on this topic, around 42 percent pointed to high competition as the main challenge, a third confessed to not having relevant professional experience. Another challenge mentioned was the mismatch between skills and the demands of the Macau job market. The mismatch between young people's abilities and work demands, combined with the lack of opportunities to develop advanced skills and the high cost of professional certifications was identified as one of the biggest obstacles to starting a career. When it comes to developing skills, almost half of those surveyed pointed to language training as their preferred choice, followed by what the survey authors called “interpersonal skills” (solving complex problems and negotiating skills). The other skills listed by the young people were management and leadership skills. Lack of space Regarding training actions, the survey by the General Women's Association reveals that almost 50 percent of young people want to access practical courses on digital content (such as Artificial Intelligence and mega-data). On the other hand, around 46 percent would like to attend internationally recognized professional certification courses. Furthermore, more than half of young people stated that Macau's labor market is too small, with no advanced skills development projects or internationally recognized professional training plans. The time and financial cost of this type of training was highlighted as an obstacle to professional progression by more than 37 percent of respondents. In terms of priorities in the labor market, almost 75 percent of respondents indicated that they prioritized wages, the balance between work and free time and job stability. The survey was carried out online, between October and November, among residents aged between 18 and 45, with 568 valid responses. During the presentation of the study results, deputies Wong Kit Cheng and Loi I Weng made recommendations to address the challenges enumerated by young people. The first suggestions were policies that the Government has indicated for years as priorities, such as the construction of the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin and the adequate diversification of the economy. The deputies also asked for an increase in support for the Training and Accreditation Exams Program for Qualified Personnel to at least 10 thousand patacas.

item.title: Car insurance | Request for review of coverage values
item.description: Without any change for 15 years, the deputy linked to the Fujian community questions the Government about the revision of the minimum insurance value, which is currently 750 thousand patacas for mopeds and 1.5 million patacas for motorcycles and cars Representative Song Pek Kei defends the need to increase the minimum amount of civil liability insurance coverage for traffic accidents. The matter was addressed through a written interpellation, with the legislator warning that the party responsible for the accident often finds it difficult to pay compensation. Song indicates that currently if residents opt for the cheapest insurance, the maximum amount that insurers have to cover is MOP750,000 if they drive a moped, or MOP1.5 million if the vehicle driven is a car or motorcycle. However, the legislator considers the values ​​to be inappropriate because they have remained unchanged “for 15 years”, despite social development. The deputy linked to the Fujian community also points out that as the median income of residents is close to 20 thousand patacas and “the compensation awarded by the courts for a single traffic accident normally exceeds the minimum limit of insurance coverage” the party considered responsible finds it difficult to “provide reasonable compensation to the victim” of the accident. For these reasons, and because the coverage amount is “inadequate to respond to social developments”, Song questions the Government about whether it will increase the minimum coverage amount to respond to “the growing demand for compensation”. The deputy also suggests the creation of a mechanism for regularly reviewing the amount to avoid problems like the current one, in which the coverage value regularly deviates from reality. Excessive compensation? In the interpellation, Song Pek Kei also considers that the compensation determined by the courts must be reasonable, to keep pace with social developments. “Excessively high amounts of compensation impose an unreasonable burden on the responsible parties and are not in line with the evolution of contemporary society”, he pointed out. According to Song, the issue is the fact that court decisions regularly condemn those responsible for accidents to cover non-material damages, such as mental suffering and loss of future income. As the insurance only covers “bodily damage and partial material damage”, the deputy indicates that those sentenced to pay are regularly in difficulty paying compensation. Furthermore, the legislator wants clarification on the possibility of insurance covering the types of compensation that are now left out.

item.title: University of Macau | Former teachers recall experiences
item.description: The University of Macau celebrates 45 years and HM invited two former professors to recall their professional experiences at the institution. Brian Hall, from the field of psychology, found “the ideal environment” to start his career. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” and saw Law as a “meeting place” A series of events begins this Sunday to celebrate the 45 years of existence of the University of Macau (UM), including the “Open Day” which takes place at the Lakeside Theater between 11am and 5pm (see secondary text). It was in March 1981, still under the name of the University of East Asia, that UM began to take its first steps in local higher education, namely in the teaching of Law in the Portuguese language. It was the first time that Macau had its own university, providing a higher education offering for residents, who no longer only had the opportunity to pursue studies abroad, such as Portugal, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong or Australia. To commemorate the anniversary, HM invited two former professors of the institution, from two different academic areas, to talk about their experience at UM. Vera Lúcia Raposo, who taught at the Faculty of Law from January 2014, remembers feeling “a shock”. "The classes were entirely in English, and I had never taught a complete course in that language, the pressure to publish in indexed journals was absolute and the evaluation system was periodic, demanding and relentless. Nothing there resembled the regime I was used to, where the simple passage of time often seemed to guarantee the natural advancement of an academic career", she said. However, adaptation arrived and ended up following “the rules” to this day, namely at NOVA School of Law. “At the time, however, these requirements were still profoundly strange in Portugal, and they continue to be so, in many contexts, even today”, he says. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” at UM, as “the demanding scientific production goals and interdisciplinary research contributed to defining the type of academic I am today”. “I owe UM more than a professional transition, but a transformation”, he assures. A cultural melting pot The former professor at the UM Faculty of Law also remembers arriving in a territory that was “a space of true cultural amalgamation”, with the institution being an example of this. "Working side by side with colleagues of different nationalities and cultures was a rare privilege. In particular, the intellectual coexistence between Chinese, Macanese and Portuguese colleagues, in the study and teaching of Macau Law, offered me an absolutely unique way of thinking about Law: less self-centered, more dialoguing, more aware of its cultural and historical contingency", highlighted Vera Lúcia Raposo. Brian Hall, who taught at the Faculty of Social Sciences and coordinated the “Global and Community Mental Health Research Group”, highlights the possibility of doing pioneering work in the area of ​​mental health. "UM gave me the opportunity to develop unique and never-before-taught courses in Global Mental Health and Global Health. They were the first courses of their kind in Macau and at the university", recalled Brian Hall, who is now linked to New York University Shanghai. “I was grateful to have some really great students who were interested in topics like migration, global and digital mental health, and I really enjoyed mentoring them in and out of the classroom.” The first prizes The academic also highlights the fact that he “regularly published research articles with undergraduate and postgraduate students, taking them to international research conferences, where they won awards”. “We were among the first at the university to achieve these excellent results and I am eternally grateful to UM for providing me with all these opportunities”, he confessed. Brian Hall also added that he joined UM “in a period of ambitious transition and growth to become a research university”, providing “an ideal environment to launch a career”. When he was at UM, Brian Hall received, in 2020, an award for his work, the “Excellence in Advising Award” from the Center for Global Health at Johns Hopkins University, from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. "The university rewarded me for my excellent research performance by granting me permission to apply for an early promotion to associate professor, which I was granted just four years after joining the university. UM served as a springboard to build a regional and international career," he said. Book of Genesis The need to create a university in Macau arose from the desire to develop the territory, especially taking into account the signing of the Joint Declaration between Portugal and China in 1987. The former Governor of Macau Garcia Leandro recalled the first moments of the creation of the future university in the book “Macau in the Years of the Portuguese Revolution 1974-1979”, which reads that the initial budget was 40 million patacas for construction “on land on the island of Taipa, with a modern architectural project”. The institution should have capacity for “a population of two thousand students in four years, at a rate of 500 per year”, with “the leadership of the various course chairs guaranteed by a dean professor with a doctorate from the University of Oxford and by several university professors from Matteo Ricci, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and also from the USA”, it is described. The first contract to train the teaching team and pedagogical content was signed in February 1979 with the Matteo Ricci group. “I believe it was another good service provided to the population”, wrote the former Governor. In 1991, the institution changed its name to what it currently has. According to data from the 2024 annual report, the latest available, UM has 52,146 graduated students, and in the first semester of the 2024/2025 academic year, 15,147 students attended the university, from all educational levels. Highlight is the greater number of students from abroad, 9,328, compared to 5,819 local students. Open day in Hengqin Despite having been formally created in March, UM begins to celebrate 45 years of existence this Sunday with an Open Day. According to a statement from the educational institution, between 11 am and 5 pm the public will be able to visit the Lakeside Theater, where the first ceremony takes place, and then other areas of the campus in Hengqin, namely the main campus and the UM Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Zhuhai, in the Youth Entrepreneurship Valley in Hengqin. This route also includes the possibility of visiting, for the first time, the Transitional Research and Education Site at Yuxin Tower, in the Cooperation Zone. “Through a wide range of on-site activities and live online broadcasts, the event will showcase UM’s latest developments and achievements in teaching, research and community service”, highlights the same note, which recalls how UM was the first higher education institution in Macau to “extend teaching and research activities to the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin”. That day there will also be “approximately 250 activities on the main campus throughout the day, including admissions lectures, academic and research activities and interactive games”. "Visitors interested in academic subjects can attend engaging lectures on science and other disciplines, while sports enthusiasts can explore UM's sports facilities. Families can also participate in interactive games at stands, scientific experiments, workshops and knowledge challenges organized by various faculties, residences and laboratories", it is revealed. On Open Day there will also be discounts in the restaurant area.

item.title: First retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida in Asia opens on the 23rd
item.description: The Macau Museum of Art (MAM) will open the first retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida (1934-2018) in Asia on January 23, announced one of the exhibition's curators. The exhibition “Helena Almeida: I'm Here – Presença and Resonance” is “one of the most comprehensive ever presented” and will be on display until April 26, Margarida Saraiva said on social media. The MAM curator stated that the retrospective will be divided into five sections, “chronologically and thematically”, including one dedicated to the first paintings and another to “the body as sculpture and the dialogue between bodies”. Saraiva named Helena Almeida as “one of the most relevant Portuguese and European artists of her generation”, who “transformed the act of self-representation into an intense exploration of the body, space, resilience and impermanence”. “His performative gestures — captured only through the lens of his studio — continue to challenge and expand the limits of painting, drawing and photography,” explained the curator. “This exhibition is simultaneously a tribute to Helena Almeida’s extraordinary legacy and an affirmation of the power of curatorial collaboration between cultures”, argued Saraiva. The retrospective's main curator is Delfim Sardo, professor at the University of Coimbra and author of the book “Helena Almeida, Pés no Chão, Cabeça no Céu”, and the Chinese Song Zhen as co-curator. Divide by two In December, the Macau Cultural Institute indicated in a statement that the exhibition will bring together around 42 sets made up of 190 pieces by the Portuguese artist. Another part of the exhibition, “Resonância – Corpo. Objecto. Reflexão”, was opened on December 19, with pieces by six artists from Macau and mainland China, invited to interact with the work of Helena Almeida. Born in Lisbon in 1934, Helena Almeida created, from the 1960s onwards, a multifaceted work, giving rise to a work that stood out for its self-representation, reflecting on the tension relationships between the body, space and the work. He used his body as a support and creative object, using painting, photography, engraving, installation and video. Helena Almeida studied painting at the Escola Superior de Belas-Artes in Lisbon, beginning to exhibit individually in 1967, at Galeria Buchholz. The artist represented Portugal at the Venice Biennale on two occasions: in 1982 and 2005, and in 2004 she participated in the Sydney Biennale, with her work being exhibited in individual and collective exhibitions in national and international museums and galleries. In 2015, he presented a traveling solo exhibition Corpus at Fundação de Serralves (2015), in Porto, in Paris (2016), in Brussels (2016) and Valencia (2017). In 2017, he also presented a solo exhibition “Work is never finished” at the Art Institute, in Chicago, in the United States. His work is present in Portuguese and international collections such as: Berardo Collection, Lisbon; Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, Lisbon; Serralves Foundation, Porto; Hara Museum of Contemporary Art, Tokyo; Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art; Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, Madrid; MUDAM – Musée d’Art Moderne Grand-Duc Jean, Luxembourg; Tate Modern, London.

item.title: Hong Kong | Zhipu AI leads round of stock market debuts worth 1,030 ME
item.description: Investor interest in the technology market continues to bear fruit and leads more and more Chinese companies linked to Artificial Intelligence to enter the Hong Kong stock exchange The Chinese artificial intelligence company Zhipu AI debuted on the Hong Kong stock exchange yesterday, on a day when two other technology companies also entered the market, collectively raising 1.2 billion dollars. Zhipu, officially called Knowledge Atlas Technology and which adopts the name Z.ai in foreign markets, registered an upward trend in the middle of the session, with a value of 11.19 percent, after having raised around 559 million dollars. It is the first Chinese company specializing exclusively in large-scale language models to be listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. According to its co-founder and executive director, Zhang Peng, the choice of this financial center is related to the company's internationalization ambitions. Zhang said that Hong Kong and Southeast Asia will be the first markets to be explored, followed by the Middle East, Europe and the so-called “Global South”. The manager pointed to low costs as Zhipu's main attraction compared to competing models, with the aim of winning over new users. The technology company thus joins other Chinese companies in the sector that have taken advantage of investors' interest in the growth of AI in the country. One of Zhipu's main competitors, MiniMax – also a rival to OpenAI (creator of ChatGPT) and Anthropic (developer of Claude) – is scheduled to debut on the same exchange on Friday. Other premieres Yesterday, graphics chip maker Shanghai Iluvatar CoreX Semiconductor, which opened with gains of 31.5 percent after raising US$473 million, and surgical robot producer Edge Medical, which rose 36.4 percent, raising around US$154 million, also debuted in Hong Kong. Last week, Biren Technology, which specializes in AI chips, rose nearly 76 percent on its first day of trading. In December, two other companies in the sector, Moore Threads and MetaX, recorded increases of more than 100 percent on the Shanghai stock exchange. Despite admitting that Chinese models are closing the gap compared to North Americans, Zhang Peng acknowledged that gaps still persist in areas such as research, resources and innovation. Zhipu was placed on a commercial blacklist by the United States in 2025, making it difficult for it to access North American technology.

item.title: Damn | Woman arrested for heroin trafficking
item.description: A 43-year-old woman was arrested after being intercepted with 0.83 grams of heroin, valued at MOP1,000, while returning from Hong Kong. The case was revealed yesterday by the Judiciary Police and the investigation was based on a complaint. According to the PJ's version, the woman is an unemployed local resident, who had made several trips between Macau and Hong Kong with the purpose of trafficking and consuming drugs. In addition to the drugs, authorities seized syringes, packages for storing drugs and other materials for consumption. A search of the woman's house, in Coloane, also resulted in the seizure of other materials used to consume narcotics. The detainee was also tested for urine, which tested positive for drug consumption. The case was handed over to the Public Ministry (MP). Illegal exchanges | Two cases lead to the seizure of 47,900 HK dollars Authorities seized 47,900 Hong Kong dollars worth of gambling chips, which they believed were used in illegal money exchanges. The seizure resulted from two different cases, carried out by the Judiciary Police and the Public Security Police Corps. The first situation involved a 40-year-old man from the Interior, caught red-handed exchanging money with a player. The latter confessed that he had previously exchanged 300 renminbi for 300 Hong Kong dollars in tokens, which led to the first arrest and seizure of 28,500,000 Hong Kong dollars, in the possession of the suspected criminal. In turn, the first detainee claimed to have made profits from exchanging money worth 7,000 Hong Kong dollars. The second detainee, also at the casino, was also intercepted in the act. The individual is also from the Interior and, in addition to an attempt to exchange 6,000 Hong Kong dollars for 6,000 renminbis, he had 19,400,000 Hong Kong dollars in his possession.

item.title: Today Macau
item.description: Japanese authorities are investigating the loss of a professional cell phone, allegedly in China, which contained a confidential list of contacts from the Nuclear Regulation Authority, as confirmed to France-Presse by a person responsible for the organization. The incident, now made public, occurred at Shanghai airport, on November 3, when the employee was going through security control. The absence of the device was only noticed three days later, and, according to the Japanese press, it was not possible to block it or remotely erase its data as it was already out of reach. Although the cell phone did not contain direct access to nuclear data, according to the person in charge – who did not want to be identified – the list included names and contact details of members of the nuclear safety division of the regulatory authority – information that is not publicly accessible due to the sensitivity of the functions. The revelation comes in a context of growing tension between Beijing and Tokyo, after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi suggested in November that the country could intervene militarily in the event of Chinese aggression against Taiwan. At the same time, the operator Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) is seeking final approval to reactivate the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant, the largest in the world, closed after the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Japan has been gradually resuming nuclear energy, with 14 reactors already reactivated, within the framework of carbon neutrality targets by 2050 and increased demand for electricity due to artificial intelligence. The lost cellphone was reported to Japanese data protection authorities in November, according to the nuclear regulator. The case reignites concerns about information security in the nuclear energy sector at a delicate moment in Japanese energy policy.

item.title: Paulo Maia and Carmo
item.description: Mo Shilong (1537-87), referring to one of the most cherished masters in the canon of painting history, known by the name Ni Yunlin zi, the «Master of the cloud forest», the painter Nizan (1306-1374), who was revealed when, in the turmoil of the violent dynastic transition, he said «no» to those closest to him, starting to live as a recluse, noted that «when ordinary people try imitate an original painting, how can they transmit its spirit to posterity?” Later, the influential theorist Dong Qichang (1555-1636) added: «Those who study the old masters and do not introduce changes are like trapped behind a fence. By imitating models too closely you are often even further away». And Nizan's paintings, perhaps even more than many others, in their serene austere aspect will be the most difficult to imitate because they depend intimately on the person of their author and the way in which he managed to make the «spiritual rhythm» (qiyun) flow in them. And yet many tried to reproduce the elegant and insipid (dan) appearance of those visions that were closer to their spirit than to the external visible. Later, in another dynastic transition, from the Ming to the Qing dynasty, a painter tried to follow Nizan's path from within, in similar circumstances. He belonged to a family of seven brothers, from Shanyin (now part of Shaoxing, Zhejiang). One of the brothers, the illustrated imperial official Qi Biaojia (1603-45), would leave a unique record of the sophistication of the literati at the end of the Ming dynasty, significantly through the memory of his Yu garden, on the slope of the hill of the same name. In the «Yu Hill Anthology», Yushan zhi, a collective work in three volumes written by him, his friends and family, travel notes, explanations of views of the garden, narratives, inquiries, dreams of personalities who interpreted their present with knowledge of the rich arts and literature of the past are kept, constituting a relevant historical archive. Which was found expressively in paintings. Qi Zhijia (1594-c.1682), another of the brothers, in addition to being a poet, playwright, calligrapher, stamp engraver, athlete and amateur singer, had a memory of paintings, as shown in several works made in the style of great masters. If, faced with the disruption of the new foreign government, Qi Biaojia would commit suicide in his garden, as four thousand and forty-three senior officials did, according to a record from Qianlong's time, Qi Zhijia would resist through calm contemplation, accepting impermanence, as in the 1651 vertical scroll, Landscape from Nizan (ink on paper, 116 x 50.8 cm, at the Metmuseum). In him the “dragon veins”, longmo, reveal the depth of his experience of solitude and serenity, the understanding of the spirit of Winter.

item.title: Church | Pope closes 2025 with criticism of consumerism and xenophobia
item.description: Pope Leo The speech served to close the Jubilee - a Holy Year that usually takes place every 25 years, proclaimed by the Pope as a special time of forgiveness, reconciliation and spiritual renewal -, which brought around 33 million pilgrims to Rome and included a historic transition from one American pontiff to another. In the presence of cardinals and diplomats from all over the world, Leo This situation had only occurred once, in 1700. Yesterday's ceremony, at the beginning of the mass celebrating the feast of the Epiphany (when the three Magi offered gifts to the newborn Jesus) ended a dizzying year of special audiences, masses and meetings that dominated Leo XIV's first months as pontiff and put his own agenda on hold. To signal that his pontificate can now begin in earnest, the Pope summoned cardinals from around the world to the Vatican, for meetings on Wednesday and Thursday that aim to debate the governance of the Catholic Church, with its 1.4 billion faithful. To reflect In yesterday's homily, Leo XIV said that the jubilee year invited all Christians to reflect on the biblical teachings of welcoming strangers and resisting the “flattery and seduction of those who hold power”. “Around us, a distorted economy tries to profit from everything”, he criticized, adding that he hopes that this year it will be possible to recognize “a pilgrim in the visitor, a seeker abroad, a neighbor in the stranger and a traveling companion in someone who is different”. The Holy Years usually include large public works projects, as was the case with the construction of the Sistine Chapel (commissioned by Pope Sixtus IV for the Jubilee of 1475) and the large Vatican garage, where popemobiles and other vehicles are parked (commissioned by John Paul II for the Jubilee of 2000). Some works were controversial, such as the construction of Via della Conciliazione, in 1950, which leads to St. Peter's Square and which involved the demolition of an entire neighborhood. Leo XIV also announced that the next Jubilee will be in 2033, to commemorate the 2000th anniversary of what the Scriptures indicate as the death and resurrection of Jesus Christ, in 33 AD.

item.title: Medals | Ho Iat Seng, Kou Hoi In and Raimundo do Rosário distinguished
item.description: The list of winners is marked by the award of two Medals of Honor of the Great Lotus, the highest distinction in the Macao SAR, to Ho Iat Seng and Kou Hoi In. All the individuals awarded served in the Government or in the Legislative Assembly The former Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, and the former president of the Legislative Assembly, Kou Hoi In, will be awarded the Great Lotus Medal of Honor, the Macao SAR's highest distinction. The list of the Executive's distinctions for 2025 was announced on December 31st, through a statement from the Social Communication Office, and the award ceremony is scheduled for January 30th, at the Macau Cultural Center. The main distinctions awarded by Sam Hou Fai were to former rulers, with Macanese and former Secretary for Transport and Public Works Raimundo do Rosário being awarded the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. This distinction will also be awarded to Ho Veng On, former Commissioner of Audit, and Vong Man Chong, former director-general of the Customs Service. Medals of honor aim to distinguish individuals or entities that have contributed to the image and good name of the Macao SAR. After the list of medals was announced, Ho Iat Seng considered the title “a profound honor”. The former Government leader also stated, in a statement, that he “has always maintained a deep affection for Macau” and that over the years he has “dedicated” himself to “serving the nation and Macau”. The former Chief Executive praised the results of his governance and considered that they depended “not only on the dedication and hard work of the government action team and all Public Administration employees, but also on the strong support and joint efforts of the community and all residents”. “This honor is a collective victory, which demonstrates the commitment of the entire society to drive greater and better development for the Macao SAR,” he stated. The text awarding the Great Lotus Medal of Honor to Ho Iat Seng highlights the period in which the former ruler had to deal with the Covid-19 pandemic. “During his term as the fifth Chief Executive, he united the Macao SAR Government and all social sectors, successfully overcame the severe challenges and difficulties of the Covid-19 pandemic and made every effort to promote post-pandemic economic recovery and social development”, it was stated. In addition to being Chief Executive, Ho Iat Seng, a businessman by profession, was president of the Legislative Assembly, member of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress and member of the Executive Council. This is the third time that Ho Iat Seng will be honored, after in 2001 having received the Medal of Industrial and Commercial Merit and in 2009 having been distinguished with the Golden Lotus Medal of Honor. Another Lotus Another distinguished businessman and former president of the Legislative Assembly is Kou Hoi In, notable for his activity as a member of the National People's Congress, the main legislative body of the People's Republic of China, and for more than 34 years as a deputy of the Legislative Assembly. “In legislation work, supervision of government action and formulation of public policies, it has always defended the principles of carrying out functions in accordance with the law, in a rational and pragmatic manner, actively promoted the improvement of regimes and the construction of the rule of law and committed itself to safeguarding the rights and interests of residents and promoting social stability and long-term development”, it was considered. “During his term as President of the Legislative Assembly of Macau from 2019 to 2025, he focused his efforts on improving the efficiency of parliamentary functioning, promoting positive interaction between the Executive Branch and the Legislative Branch, and made important contributions to strengthening the construction of the Rule of Law, promoting social harmony and improving the population's well-being policies”, it was added. After leaving the Chamber, Kou was appointed to serve as chairman of the Board of Directors of TDM, he is also vice-president of the Board of Directors and general manager of the China Special Products and Productions Company and vice-president of the Macau Commercial Association. In the past, the previous president of AL had been awarded the Industrial and Commercial Merit Medal in 2007 and the Silver Lotus Medal of Honor in 2016. In Portuguese Raimundo do Rosário, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, between 2014 and 2024, is the only representative of the Macanese community in the 2025 distinctions, taking into account the distinguished individuals and associations. In the text about the former ruler, several positions held in public and private institutions are indicated. “He joined the Civil Service in 1979 and worked until 1990 successively as a senior technician, head of department, deputy director and director of the Land, Public Works and Transport Services”, it can be read. His CV also states that he was a member of the Portuguese delegation of the Portuguese-Chinese Land Group, deputy of the Board of Directors of CAM-Sociedade of Macau International Airport and head of the Macau Economic and Commercial Delegation, in Lisbon, also having charge of the Economic and Commercial Delegations to the European Union, in Brussels and the World Trade Organization, in Geneva. Raimundo was also a member of the Drafting Committee of the Basic Law and the Preparatory Committee for the Establishment of the Special Administrative Region of Macau, deputy and member of the Supervisory Board of Banco Comercial de Macau. In terms of medals of honor, the Macau Banks Association will be awarded the Silver Lotus, due to its “fundamental role in promoting sector collaboration and the solid development of the industry”. Medals of Merit In terms of the professional merit medal this year, only one distinction appears, for Chan Iok Lin, who has been a member of the Office of the President of the Court of Final Instance since 2000, having become head in 2016. “He has always demonstrated a rigorous and dedicated attitude in carrying out his duties, possessing excellent leadership and organizational skills, as well as a high level of professionalism and a spirit of dedication”, he was justified. In the industrial and commercial area, the distinctions went to the state-owned company Companhia de Logística Nam Kwong, from the Nam Kwong group, for its contributions to the diversification of the economy and to businesswoman Amber Li Jiaming, who is president of the HN Group and member of the 14th National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference (CPPCC), vice-president of the CPPCC Foreign Affairs Commission and member of the Council for the Economic Development of Macau. At a tourist level, the only distinction was given to the House of Dancing Water Show Team, from Melco Resorts & Entertainment. The show was suspended during the pandemic, but returned after the end of border restrictions imposed during the years of combating Covid-19. In terms of education, the Macau University of Science and Technology, Keang Peng School and Kao Yip School were distinguished. In culture, the distinctions went to the Chinese Opera Association of Maritime and Land Residents of Barra de Macau, deputy Lam Fat Iam and artist Chan Iu Pui, who draws caricatures for the newspaper Ou Mun. Finally, an Altruistic Merit Medal will be awarded to the China International Emergency Medical Team (SAR) and Sports Merit medals to the MSAR Karate Team that participated in the National Games. Athlete Zhu Yuling, who defended the colors of Interior until 2024, when she moved to Macau, will also be honored. The athlete went on to represent the Macao SAR under professional staff promotion programs and won the women's singles title in the WTT of United States Smash Table Tennis, the first athlete from Macau to achieve this feat. Currently, she is a professor at Tianjin University. item.title: Economy | Deputies warn of lack of trust and inequalities
item.description: Despite economic growth throughout this year, Chan Lai Kei and Leong Sun Iok alerted the Government to the problems in community neighborhoods and the need to distribute financial resources more equitably Deputy Chan Lai Kei called on the Government to focus on promoting economic optimism and consumption, considering that in several neighborhoods in Macau the economic situation is worrying, despite macroeconomic growth. The matter was brought to the Legislative Assembly yesterday, an intervention before the agenda in the Plenary. According to the deputy linked to the Fujian community, the economy is showing a “stable recovery”. Between January and September “the initial value of GDP grew 4.2 percent compared to the same period last year”. It also indicated that the unemployment rate was 2.3 percent between August and October. However, Chan warned that “positive macroeconomic data have not completely eliminated negative indicators”, especially with regard to the lives of the population. Citing a “recent study”, the legislator indicated that there is a weak desire to consume, because “residents’ confidence in increasing income and their satisfaction with their financial situation are still between a low and medium level”. Chan Lai Kei explained that greater consumption abroad contributes to this wave of pessimism, but also the various closures of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs): “In view of the stress of consumption abroad, the business environment of SMEs in areas linked to the lives of the population (such as NAPE, Iao Hon and Fai Chi Kei) continues to worsen and the risk of closure remains”, he warned. “These companies generally face the critical challenge of unstable customer sources, high costs and cross-border consumption”, he stressed. Given the scenario outlined, the deputy asked the Executive to create a consumption incentive mechanism similar to discount vouchers, but with a permanent nature, while the “transformation phase of Macau's economic model” lasts, which “reinforces confidence in business”. Improve distribution Deputy Leong Sun Iok also addressed the situation of the economy and pointed out the need to better distribute resources from gambling, the main industry in the territory. The legislator linked to the Federation of Workers' Associations of Macau praised the gaming concessionaires for the greater role they have taken in terms of investment for “urban development, tourism promotion and social security”, especially since 2023. However, he regretted that resources are being channeled unequally: "It appears that, currently, both the revenues from the game and the gaming concessionaire companies themselves have invested a lot of resources in social development. But, in general, these resources are dispersed and lack a system and interconnection, therefore, they are unable to achieve maximum social benefit", he pointed out. Leong thus advocated that a greater proportion of the revenue collected by the Administration from gambling be channeled to the Social Security Fund, to pay pensions for the elderly. The deputy also called for the creation of a fund with money from concessionaires to develop the Macao SAR and to ensure that they “better” fulfill the obligations of the gaming law, such as “worker guarantees”, “support for people with disabilities or those rehabilitated”, support for SMEs and “educational, scientific research, environmental protection, cultural and sporting activities and activities of public interest”. Leong Sun Iok also asked for a new portal with public information on concessionaires' expenses with non-gambling activities covered by the concessions' obligations and ended the intervention with a request for caution addressed to the Executive. “Society’s resources do not come easily and are the result of the joint efforts of the Government, companies, the various social sectors and the population in general”, he indicated. "The situation is not always good. I hope the Government makes good use of the resources arising from the social responsibilities of gaming companies, to improve the lives of the population", he highlighted. Minimum Wage | Approved increase of one pataca per hour The increase of one pataca per hour in the minimum wage, from 34 to 35 patacas, was approved yesterday in the Legislative Assembly. With the changes, starting next year, in weekly terms, the salary will go from 1,632 patacas to 1,680 patacas. When the monthly calculations are made, the salary increases from 7,072 patacas to 7,280 patacas, an increase of 2.9 percent that will cover 4.4 percent of Macao SAR workers. Domestic workers are excluded, although the approval of the hiring quota, in the case of non-residents, is normally associated with the requirement of a salary between 3,500 and 4,000 patacas. Budget 2026 | Deputies approve the specialty The Legislative Assembly yesterday approved the budget for next year, which foresees an increase in gaming revenue of 3.5 percent, to 236 billion patacas. The document, which reflects the Executive's economic choices, estimates revenues of 118.8 billion patacas, while expenses are estimated at 113.5 billion patacas. Based on these perspectives, the final balance of the regular budget should be positive at 5.3 billion patacas. However, there is a possibility that the scenario is actually better, given that the Government tends to make default estimates with regard to revenue and expenses. The budget also once again provides for exemption from paying professional tax, up to 30 percent of the annual amount, limited to 144 thousand patacas.

item.title: University of Macau | Former teachers recall experiences
item.description: The University of Macau celebrates 45 years and HM invited two former professors to recall their professional experiences at the institution. Brian Hall, from the field of psychology, found “the ideal environment” to start his career. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” and saw Law as a “meeting place” A series of events begins this Sunday to celebrate the 45 years of existence of the University of Macau (UM), including the “Open Day” which takes place at the Lakeside Theater between 11am and 5pm (see secondary text). It was in March 1981, still under the name of the University of East Asia, that UM began to take its first steps in local higher education, namely in the teaching of Law in the Portuguese language. It was the first time that Macau had its own university, providing a higher education offering for residents, who no longer only had the opportunity to pursue studies abroad, such as Portugal, the United Kingdom, Hong Kong or Australia. To commemorate the anniversary, HM invited two former professors of the institution, from two different academic areas, to talk about their experience at UM. Vera Lúcia Raposo, who taught at the Faculty of Law from January 2014, remembers feeling “a shock”. "The classes were entirely in English, and I had never taught a complete course in that language, the pressure to publish in indexed journals was absolute and the evaluation system was periodic, demanding and relentless. Nothing there resembled the regime I was used to, where the simple passage of time often seemed to guarantee the natural advancement of an academic career", she said. However, adaptation arrived and ended up following “the rules” to this day, namely at NOVA School of Law. “At the time, however, these requirements were still profoundly strange in Portugal, and they continue to be so, in many contexts, even today”, he says. Vera Lúcia Raposo says she “learned a lot” at UM, as “the demanding scientific production goals and interdisciplinary research contributed to defining the type of academic I am today”. “I owe UM more than a professional transition, but a transformation”, he assures. A cultural melting pot The former professor at the UM Faculty of Law also remembers arriving in a territory that was “a space of true cultural amalgamation”, with the institution being an example of this. "Working side by side with colleagues of different nationalities and cultures was a rare privilege. In particular, the intellectual coexistence between Chinese, Macanese and Portuguese colleagues, in the study and teaching of Macau Law, offered me an absolutely unique way of thinking about Law: less self-centered, more dialoguing, more aware of its cultural and historical contingency", highlighted Vera Lúcia Raposo. Brian Hall, who taught at the Faculty of Social Sciences and coordinated the “Global and Community Mental Health Research Group”, highlights the possibility of doing pioneering work in the area of ​​mental health. "UM gave me the opportunity to develop unique and never-before-taught courses in Global Mental Health and Global Health. They were the first courses of their kind in Macau and at the university", recalled Brian Hall, who is now linked to New York University Shanghai. “I was grateful to have some really great students who were interested in topics like migration, global and digital mental health, and I really enjoyed mentoring them in and out of the classroom.” The first prizes The academic also highlights the fact that he “regularly published research articles with undergraduate and postgraduate students, taking them to international research conferences, where they won awards”. “We were among the first at the university to achieve these excellent results and I am eternally grateful to UM for providing me with all these opportunities”, he confessed. Brian Hall also added that he joined UM “in a period of ambitious transition and growth to become a research university”, providing “an ideal environment to launch a career”. When he was at UM, Brian Hall received, in 2020, an award for his work, the “Excellence in Advising Award” from the Center for Global Health at Johns Hopkins University, from the Johns Hopkins Bloomberg School of Public Health. "The university rewarded me for my excellent research performance by granting me permission to apply for an early promotion to associate professor, which I was granted just four years after joining the university. UM served as a springboard to build a regional and international career," he said. Book of Genesis The need to create a university in Macau arose from the desire to develop the territory, especially taking into account the signing of the Joint Declaration between Portugal and China in 1987. The former Governor of Macau Garcia Leandro recalled the first moments of the creation of the future university in the book “Macau in the Years of the Portuguese Revolution 1974-1979”, which reads that the initial budget was 40 million patacas for construction “on land on the island of Taipa, with a modern architectural project”. The institution should have capacity for “a population of two thousand students in four years, at a rate of 500 per year”, with “the leadership of the various course chairs guaranteed by a dean professor with a doctorate from the University of Oxford and by several university professors from Matteo Ricci, the Chinese University of Hong Kong and also from the USA”, it is described. The first contract to train the teaching team and pedagogical content was signed in February 1979 with the Matteo Ricci group. “I believe it was another good service provided to the population”, wrote the former Governor. In 1991, the institution changed its name to what it currently has. According to data from the 2024 annual report, the latest available, UM has 52,146 graduated students, and in the first semester of the 2024/2025 academic year, 15,147 students attended the university, from all educational levels. Highlight is the greater number of students from abroad, 9,328, compared to 5,819 local students. Open day in Hengqin Despite having been formally created in March, UM begins to celebrate 45 years of existence this Sunday with an Open Day. According to a statement from the educational institution, between 11 am and 5 pm the public will be able to visit the Lakeside Theater, where the first ceremony takes place, and then other areas of the campus in Hengqin, namely the main campus and the UM Scientific and Technological Research Institute in Zhuhai, in the Youth Entrepreneurship Valley in Hengqin. This route also includes the possibility of visiting, for the first time, the Transitional Research and Education Site at Yuxin Tower, in the Cooperation Zone. “Through a wide range of on-site activities and live online broadcasts, the event will showcase UM’s latest developments and achievements in teaching, research and community service”, highlights the same note, which recalls how UM was the first higher education institution in Macau to “extend teaching and research activities to the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin”. That day there will also be “approximately 250 activities on the main campus throughout the day, including admissions lectures, academic and research activities and interactive games”. "Visitors interested in academic subjects can attend engaging lectures on science and other disciplines, while sports enthusiasts can explore UM's sports facilities. Families can also participate in interactive games at stands, scientific experiments, workshops and knowledge challenges organized by various faculties, residences and laboratories", it is revealed. On Open Day there will also be discounts in the restaurant area.

item.title: UCM | White Paper suggests methods to accelerate economic diversification
item.description: The “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, produced at the City University of Macau, refers to inequalities in the relationship between countries and concludes that “economic diversification has advanced at a slow pace”. Bárbara Morais, main writer of the document, explains the main conclusions of the analysis On December 3rd, a White Paper was launched that provides a look and analysis of the way in which cooperation in scientific and technological areas between China, Macau and Portuguese-speaking countries has been taking place, outlining some criticisms, not only on this topic, but also on the economic direction that the Macao SAR is taking. The document, entitled “White Paper on Scientific and Technological Cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries”, was produced by the City University of Macau (UCM) and had Bárbara Morais, a doctoral student at the institution, as main writer. In an interview with HM, she describes that, in Macau, “economic diversification has advanced at a slower pace than desired, keeping the economy structurally dependent on gambling and tourism”. "The central message of the White Paper is clear: Macau needs to accelerate the transition to functions with greater added value. However, the current context offers a renewed window of opportunity. With the support of the Greater Bay Area and, very specifically, the Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin, Macau now has new structural opportunities to recover lost momentum and reposition itself, not just as a cultural bridge, but as a true platform for innovation", he said. Still on the territory, but in relation to Forum Macau, the “success in institutionalizing political dialogue” is mentioned, but the White Paper “points the finger at the insufficiency of execution mechanisms”. “To streamline the role of the Forum and transform it into a tool for tangible results, the White Paper advocates a paradigm shift: it is necessary to move from declarations of intent to technicality”, describes Bárbara Morais. The doctoral student suggests “the creation of specialized technical working groups, especially in the technological sphere, and the rigorous definition of performance indicators, such as the number of registered patents, startups created or joint research projects”. “At the same time, it is suggested to establish a common agenda focused on areas of the future, such as green energy, health, the maritime economy and artificial intelligence, subject to a periodic assessment of progress”, he also said. The place of arbitration Taking these meager developments into account, the White Paper suggests that Macau assert itself “as a center for technological arbitration and intellectual property governance”. HM questioned Bárbara Morais about what should be done in effective terms, taking into account the existence, for several years, of an arbitration center, and the fact that it has been a topic on the territory's political agenda for a long time. The doctoral student highlights that “in order for these ideas, debated for years, to stop being rhetoric and become reality, the Macao SAR needs to create a legal framework specialized in technological disputes aligned with the most demanding international standards”. "It is essential to attract international experts and arbitrators through competitive incentives and establish an arbitration center that enjoys recognition both in Portuguese-speaking countries and in the Greater Bay Area. The objective is to develop mediation, certification and management services for intellectual property assets, positioning Macau as a 'safe haven', neutral and efficient, for the resolution of international technological disputes", he added. Unequal cooperation In global terms, and with regard to cooperation between China and Portuguese-speaking Countries (PLP), the White Paper refers to “top planning” by Beijing for cooperation in universities and scientific research. However, planning “does not translate, linearly, into equally effective execution mechanisms on the ground, nor does it guarantee homogeneous results among the nine Portuguese-speaking countries”. Planning implies “clear guidelines, defined priorities and diplomatic instruments mobilized to guide this cooperation”, with policies such as “Made in China 2025” or the “Digital Silk Road”, which “integrate technological cooperation with the PLP into the very core of Chinese foreign policy and national innovation”, highlights the author. However, there are “inequalities, which are perhaps the most striking feature of this relationship”, as Bárbara Morais explains. “The current scenario reveals a profound asymmetry, characterized by a ‘bicephaly’ in cooperation. (…) The main scientific capabilities, the robust technological infrastructure and the volume of effective cooperation are overwhelmingly concentrated in Portugal and Brazil”. On the contrary, “Portuguese-speaking African countries (PALOP) and Timor-Leste have a significantly lower participation”. According to Bárbara Morais, the “disparity does not arise from a lack of political will, but rather from structural funding limitations, a shortage of qualified human resources and the fragility of local research institutions”. Thus, there is “two-speed cooperation, very asymmetrical within the Portuguese-speaking community itself”. The White Paper highlights the “historic crossroads” in relation to cooperation between China and the PLP, which means “the urgent need to move from potential to implementation” in this matter. "There are ambitious visions and strategic plans, but practical results remain below what is possible. To resolve this crossroads, the proposed path involves strengthening execution mechanisms, investing massively in talent and technical-scientific education, creating ecosystems of genuine collaborative innovation between China, Macau and the PLP, and, above all, having the courage to measure results and reformulate strategies based on empirical evidence, abandoning the discourse of circumstance in favor of economic and scientific pragmatism." Gaps in Africa Another of the conclusions of the White Paper is the “tenuity” of academic links with the African continent, which Bárbara Morais describes as a “fragile scenario”. “There is a triad of factors: the scarcity of installed scientific capacity, the chronic lack of funding and consistent mobility programs”, without forgetting “the absence of stable joint research structures”. “To bridge this gap and create a lasting critical mass, the White Paper is not limited to diagnosis, suggesting concrete measures such as the robust reinforcement of research grants, the creation of joint doctoral programs, the implementation of collaborative laboratories and the design of academic mobility mechanisms specifically oriented to the African reality”, he adds. The document also talks about the negative impact of “geopolitical asymmetries”, such as the “technological restrictions of the European Union and NATO on Portugal”. According to Bárbara Morais, “real and restrictive impacts” are at stake. "These limitations condition the participation of Portugal and, by extension, of other Portuguese-speaking actors that cooperate in a network with Lisbon, in high-technology projects that involve China. The impact is particularly sensitive in critical areas such as 5G telecommunications, defense, artificial intelligence and cybersecurity, creating barriers that require complex diplomatic navigation." New strategies The White Paper was developed at the UCM Research Institute on Portuguese-Speaking Countries, and written by Bárbara Morais with the participation of academic João Simões. The project is based on a review of academic literature on the topic and also on the results of the “Technological Cooperation Launch Seminar”, held on July 22, 2025 at UCM. The work analyzes areas such as “strategic evolution”, “institutional mechanisms”, “technological milestones” and “structural challenges”, aiming to “provide evidence-based strategies to transform the potential of the China-PLP partnership into a concrete reality, creating a new model of technological cooperation for the Global South”, says a statement from UCM.

item.title: Australia | Twelve killed in attack during Jewish festival
item.description: At least twelve people died and many injured were transported to Sydney hospitals yesterday, after a shooting attack on the Australian beach of Bondi, while a Jewish celebration was taking place. “There are two people in police custody on Bondi beach”, reported the New South Wales State Police on its X account, which asks “the public to avoid the area”. Citing police sources, the AFP news agency reports that the attack caused ten deaths. O serviço de ambulâncias de Nova Gales do Sul confirmou à televisão ABC que, pelo menos 16 pessoas foram transportadas para seis centros hospitalares da região. Several witnesses report that it was a shooting attack carried out by an as yet undetermined number of armed people, but the authorities have not confirmed this information either. A British tourist told French news agency AFP that he saw “two gunmen dressed in black and armed with semi-automatic rifles”. Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has already issued a statement lamenting the “shocking and distressing scenes” coming from Bondi and confirmed the existence of injuries. Part of the beach was the scene of a celebration of the Jewish festival of Hanukkah, which began yesterday and, although Australian authorities have not yet made any connection with the incident, the President of Israel, Isaac Herzog, denounced what he classified as a “vile terrorist attack against the Jews who were lighting the first candles” of the religious festival. "Our heart is with them. The heart of the entire nation of Israel beats strong at this precise moment, as we pray for the recovery of the injured, we pray for them and we pray for those who lost their lives," he said in an official statement.

item.title: Crime | Government does not release data on suicides and attempts
item.description:
After the Health Services, the Security department also stopped publishing data on suicides and attempts, after ten years of publication. The absence was noted in the release of crime data for the months of January to September this year, which show the increase in sexual abuse of minors to almost double
The Government stopped publishing data on suicide cases in Macau, as well as attempts. The absence of these numbers was noted by the newspaper Cheng Pou when it released crime data for the months of January and September this year on Friday. The publication even questions whether “the data on suicide has become ‘the secret that cannot be said’ of the authorities, committed to building a happy Macau”, remembering that this data began to be released in 2015. Highlight is the fact that the Health Services also stopped publishing the statistics, something that was done every three months. In the case of the Security Secretariat, the data was monthly and was broken down by sex, age group and methods used. The lack of numbers comes after Macau broke records in terms of suicide cases in 2024, registering 90 deaths, 2.27 percent more than in 2023. Compared to 2022, the increase was 12.5 percent. Of the 90 cases, 48 ​​concerned male victims and 42 female victims, aged between 12 and 76 years. The most recent data, for the first half of this year, reveals 41 deaths by suicide and 101 attempts. In the release of crime statistics, on Friday, only one case of death by suicide appears in relation to an episode of homicide between brothers, which occurred in August this year, in the north zone. Here, the older brother jumped from the balcony, being suspected of having killed his younger brother due to financial disputes. Break in crime Looking at the crime panorama in general terms, there is a drop of 7.1 percent in the months under analysis, compared to the same period last year. The territory's authorities highlighted the sharp drop in computer crimes. The Secretary for Security, Chan Tsz King, said that the drop is due to the “decreasing trend” of “crimes that attract more attention from society”, including serious violent crime, theft, robbery, fraud and computer crimes. In the first nine months of the year, 187 violent crimes were recorded, which represents a drop of 11 percent compared to the same period in 2024 (210). Thefts, robberies and frauds fell by 7.7, 5.9 and 23.6 percent, respectively. Computer crime, which recorded 770 cases in the first nine months of 2024, showed a decline of 52.1 percent in the period under analysis, with 369 cases. The decline in cases of fraud using telecommunications, cyber fraud and computer fraud, said Chan Tsz King, “reflects the effectiveness of the prevention and combat work carried out by the police, and the significant increase in public awareness about fraud prevention”, he said. The Government also highlighted that crime related to illicit gambling increased by 985 percent between January and September this year, with 394 more cases compared to the same period in 2024. The increase is due to the entry into force, in October last year, of the law to combat illicit gambling crimes, which introduced “the new crime of ‘exploitation of illicit exchange for gambling’ and expanded the scope of coverage of some crimes related to illicit gambling”. For the same reason, said the secretary, gambling-related crimes soared in the first three quarters of 2025 – 1,737 cases, 70.1 percent more than in the same period last year. In the past, the official said, fraud committed by people illegally exchanging money outside casinos “could not be identified as related to gambling”. “However, with the criminalization of ‘illegal money exchange’ and the improvement of legal provisions”, these cases “are now included in gambling crime statistics, thus increasing the number of crimes”, he indicated. More abuse of minors Chan Tsz King, who took office in October and presented the crime report for the first time on Friday, also referred to a 6.1 percent increase in crimes against the person, with child sexual abuse increasing by 86.7 percent, from 15 cases in the first nine months of 2024 to 28 cases in the same period this year. The secretary explained that these are essentially “voluntary sexual acts between people of the same age”, with “transmission of photographs and pornographic images”, without forgetting cases of “less serious sexual harassment”. “Cases involving people with family relationships were also identified, which deserves the attention of society”, said Chan Tsz King, who released data on awareness-raising actions on this problem: more than 70 activities carried out by the police, which saw the participation of more than 12,000 people, including students, guardians and teaching staff. Drug trafficking and sale and drug consumption, in turn, registered an increase of 37.1 percent, with 13 more cases, and 72.7 percent, eight more cases, respectively. According to the secretary's presentation, the 48 cases registered in the three quarters and the respective increase are due to “the discovery of several cases of cross-border drug trafficking through the reinforcement of internal and external police cooperation”, highlighting a case that occurred in September, when 31 kilos of cannabis flower worth 31.77 million patacas were seized. Chan Tsz King said that this was “the biggest case of cannabis smuggling seized in the history of Macau”. Between walls In the case of the crime of rape, there was a decline in the number of rape crimes, to a total of 24 cases, 40 percent less than in the same period of the previous year. The Secretary for Security added that “more than 70 percent of the victims were not residents of Macau”, and “the majority of these crimes occurred in hotel rooms”, while “a number of these involved pecuniary conflicts between the victims and the suspects, and it is not possible to rule out the hypothesis that some of the cases occurred in the context of a sexual transaction”. In this context, the secretary clarified that the police authorities have been “in close communication with the hotel sector”, and “police devices and inspections in peripheral areas of hotels and casinos” have been reinforced. Between January and September, more than 160 police actions were carried out to combat prostitution, with 192 people suspected of engaging in prostitution activity being intercepted. Furthermore, during the period in question, 17 cases of pimping or exploitation of prostitution were resolved, with the arrest of 26 suspects.
