Silence as always Questionado pela Lusa durante a conferência de imprensa sobre o primeiro caso a ser investigado em Macau no âmbito da segurança nacional, o secretário não fez comentários. “O caso (…) está a ser tratado pelas entidades judiciais e, devido ao sigilo, não seria adequado ao secretário da Segurança comentar”, completou Chan Tsz King, que era Procurador do Ministério Público quando o ex-deputado Au Kam San foi detido. At the end of July, the territory's police announced the arrest of Au Kam San, the first under the state security defense law, which came into force in 2009, with the scope being expanded 14 years later. The accusation is not yet known and there is no information about who will defend the former deputy. With Lusa

item.title: Entertainment Zone | Government admits change of purpose
item.description: The Secretary for Social Affairs and Culture, O Lam, admitted, in this Wednesday's debate in the Legislative Assembly (AL), that the Open Air Performance Zone, in Cotai, could host other types of community activities than just concerts. In response to an oral question from deputy Chan Lai Kei, the secretary stated that, after a year of experimental use, the intention is to “expand and reinforce the functions of the venue”, with “the spaces available between concerts being used to transform the venue into 3×3 basketball courts or spaces for family sporting activities”. The Zone will therefore be “a space open to citizens in order to increase flexibility and general benefits of use”. “Regarding the issue raised regarding the introduction of diverse events such as cultural and creative fairs, among others, the Government will maintain an open attitude in the evaluation process”, said the secretary.

item.title: Housing | Chan Lai Kei warns Government of infiltration problems
item.description: Deputy Chan Lai Kei alerted the Government to the needs of residents who have leaks at home and are unable to contact their neighbors to resolve the problem. The matter was addressed through a written interpellation, in which the deputy indicated that there are currently 1,700 buildings in Macau that present structural aging problems. “As both residents and buildings age, water leaks and blocked sewers caused by aging building drainage systems have become persistent problems that bother residents,” the congressman wrote. In view of this situation, the deputy indicates that the Interservice Center for the Treatment of Water Infiltration in Public Administration Buildings received more than 1,900 requests for assistance and information between January and 12 December. “Almost 90 percent were resolved through mediation, but approximately 152 cases remained unresolved as owners failed to comply or cooperate after mediation,” he revealed. “Residents who face water infiltration problems are constantly faced with three major difficulties: obtaining access to the property, carrying out inspections and obtaining compensation”, he warned. The legislator therefore asks the Government to promote a campaign on the obligation of property owners who refuse to cooperate with neighbors to resolve infiltrations. The deputy also asks the Executive to take “preventive” measures to deal with these problems.

item.title: Inquiry | More than half of young people disappointed with salaries
item.description: A survey by the General Women's Association reveals that more than half of young people think salaries are below expectations and a third admit to a lack of professional experience. In terms of training, almost half of those surveyed would like to have more proficiency in languages The Macau General Women's Association yesterday presented a survey focused on youth employment. When looking for a job, or changing professional careers, more than 50 percent of young people surveyed indicated that salaries and benefits are below their expectations. Still on this topic, around 42 percent pointed to high competition as the main challenge, a third confessed to not having relevant professional experience. Another challenge mentioned was the mismatch between skills and the demands of the Macau job market. The mismatch between young people's abilities and work demands, combined with the lack of opportunities to develop advanced skills and the high cost of professional certifications was identified as one of the biggest obstacles to starting a career. When it comes to developing skills, almost half of those surveyed pointed to language training as their preferred choice, followed by what the survey authors called “interpersonal skills” (solving complex problems and negotiating skills). The other skills listed by the young people were management and leadership skills. Lack of space Regarding training actions, the survey by the General Women's Association reveals that almost 50 percent of young people want to access practical courses on digital content (such as Artificial Intelligence and mega-data). On the other hand, around 46 percent would like to attend internationally recognized professional certification courses. Furthermore, more than half of young people stated that Macau's labor market is too small, with no advanced skills development projects or internationally recognized professional training plans. The time and financial cost of this type of training was highlighted as an obstacle to professional progression by more than 37 percent of respondents. In terms of priorities in the labor market, almost 75 percent of respondents indicated that they prioritized wages, the balance between work and free time and job stability. The survey was carried out online, between October and November, among residents aged between 18 and 45, with 568 valid responses. During the presentation of the study results, deputies Wong Kit Cheng and Loi I Weng made recommendations to address the challenges enumerated by young people. The first suggestions were policies that the Government has indicated for years as priorities, such as the construction of the Deep Cooperation Zone between Guangdong and Macau in Hengqin and the adequate diversification of the economy. The deputies also asked for an increase in support for the Training and Accreditation Exams Program for Qualified Personnel to at least 10 thousand patacas.

item.title: Great Bay | Promised alignment of social security systems
item.description: The governments of Guangdong and Macau reiterated their commitment to deepen cooperation in labor and social security matters, during a tour of a Macao SAR delegation to Guangzhou, Jiangmen and Zhongshan. The delegation made up of representatives from the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL) and the Social Security Fund participated in seminars and visited public service and professional training centers. During the visits, Macao SAR representatives and Guangdong authorities agreed on details to implement professional internships for young people from Macau, as well as a social security data sharing mechanism between Guangdong and Macau. Reciprocal recognition of the levels of professional techniques and exams for “training qualified personnel with technical skills in the area of ​​rehabilitation due to work accidents” was also promised. Regarding the visits themselves, the Macau delegation was at the Administrative Services Center in Jiangmen to analyze the process of social security services provided by Balcão Único to Macau residents and industrial projects set up in the city. In Zhongshan, the delegation visited the technician training institute, “where it observed the national training base for Western confectionery and pastry, learning about the training work of the aforementioned qualified staff”, DSAL said in a statement yesterday.

item.title: Airport | Facial recognition speeds up security checks
item.description: The company that manages Macau International Airport announced yesterday the entry into operation of the new facial recognition system in the area of ​​security control, after a one-week trial period. The Macau International Airport Society specified that the system now allows passengers to go through security control in two minutes (without the need to open hand luggage or body searches). Passengers over 11 years old, who have electronic travel documents, can register at check-in counters, self-service kiosks or electronic security gates. Once registered, facial recognition is associated with passport and boarding pass data, allowing you to proceed to the plane without showing physical documents or your travel ticket. It was added that, currently, all doors connected to the boarding gates connected to bridges to the plane are "equipped with self-boarding systems for the convenience of passengers. The facial recognition system is part of the security area modernization plan at the airport which involves an investment of 43 million patacas.

item.title: Car insurance | Request for review of coverage values
item.description: Without any change for 15 years, the deputy linked to the Fujian community questions the Government about the revision of the minimum insurance value, which is currently 750 thousand patacas for mopeds and 1.5 million patacas for motorcycles and cars Representative Song Pek Kei defends the need to increase the minimum amount of civil liability insurance coverage for traffic accidents. The matter was addressed through a written interpellation, with the legislator warning that the party responsible for the accident often finds it difficult to pay compensation. Song indicates that currently if residents opt for the cheapest insurance, the maximum amount that insurers have to cover is MOP750,000 if they drive a moped, or MOP1.5 million if the vehicle driven is a car or motorcycle. However, the legislator considers the values ​​to be inappropriate because they have remained unchanged “for 15 years”, despite social development. The deputy linked to the Fujian community also points out that as the median income of residents is close to 20 thousand patacas and “the compensation awarded by the courts for a single traffic accident normally exceeds the minimum limit of insurance coverage” the party considered responsible finds it difficult to “provide reasonable compensation to the victim” of the accident. For these reasons, and because the coverage amount is “inadequate to respond to social developments”, Song questions the Government about whether it will increase the minimum coverage amount to respond to “the growing demand for compensation”. The deputy also suggests the creation of a mechanism for regularly reviewing the amount to avoid problems like the current one, in which the coverage value regularly deviates from reality. Excessive compensation? In the interpellation, Song Pek Kei also considers that the compensation determined by the courts must be reasonable, to keep pace with social developments. “Excessively high amounts of compensation impose an unreasonable burden on the responsible parties and are not in line with the evolution of contemporary society”, he pointed out. According to Song, the issue is the fact that court decisions regularly condemn those responsible for accidents to cover non-material damages, such as mental suffering and loss of future income. As the insurance only covers “bodily damage and partial material damage”, the deputy indicates that those sentenced to pay are regularly in difficulty paying compensation. Furthermore, the legislator wants clarification on the possibility of insurance covering the types of compensation that are now left out.

item.title: Young people | Joey Lao asks for increased allowance for first job
item.description: Currently, companies that hire young people for their first job can receive up to 15 thousand patacas, the deputy linked to the Jiangmen community defends the need to “keep up with the times” and make “appropriate adjustments” to the amount Deputy Joey Lao defended strengthening support for hiring young people looking for their first job. The request was made through a written interpellation, published on the Legislative Assembly portal. According to the legislator linked to the Jiangmen community, the current subsidy for Hiring Young People Looking for their First Job has been in force since 2004, without significant changes, which means that it no longer corresponds to the current reality. “After more than two decades in force, certain provisions of the regulation have become manifestly out of step with the demands of Macau’s economic and social development”, pointed out Joey Lao. The first problem identified by the deputy is the fact that the value of support “has remained unchanged for 21 years”. The economist also explains that since 2004, employers who hire people with educational qualifications equivalent to secondary education receive “only” a subsidy of 12 thousand patacas. This support is delivered over six months, corresponding to an amount of 2 thousand patacas per month. The current form of the subsidy also defines that young people hired with qualifications corresponding to higher education receive a total support of 15 thousand patacas, distributed over six monthly installments of 2,500 patacas. Given the new context of greater difficulty in finding a job for young people, which the deputy simply defines as the need to “keep up with the times”, Joey Lao wants to know if the Executive will make “appropriate adjustments to the amount of the subsidy”. The question of age In addition to the value of the subsidy, the deputy also asks to consider increasing the age limit for granting the subsidy by the Directorate of Services for Labor Affairs (DSAL). According to current regulations, the subsidy can only be distributed to young people under the age of 26, which in Joey Lao's view “does not cover the increasingly large group of young people [over 26 years old] looking for work”. The deputy defends the need for changes also with the fact that in the case of the Financing Plan for Professional Careers of Young People in Macau in the Greater Bay Area, the Government sets the age limit at 35 years. With this support, the Executive finances the careers of those who move to Mainland China with an amount of 5 thousand patacas per month, which can reach 90 thousand patacas. Given the discrepancy, Joey Lao argues that the subsidy to support the hiring of young people looking for their first job should cover people aged up to 35 years.

item.title: Waiting for the light
item.description: There are those who say that when God closes a door, he always opens a window. What if both are closed? What happens to those inside? Well, either they suffocate to death or they get bored to death. In recent years, stores in Macau have been closing one after another. When everyone expected a window to be opened for the business to prosper, the right to open the window was given to certain contractors. Social enterprises are not commercial entities and the outcome of granting them exclusive management of commercial activities is not difficult to predict. If the planning were viable, the operation of the Canídromo Yat Yuen in Macau and the Jockey Club in Taipa should have been handed over to community organizations a long time ago. I recently had dinner at a hotel that once had a casino. I noticed that the hotel's parking lot was abandoned and several floors of this building, which housed several stores, are currently empty. After asking what had happened, I learned that, in addition to the closure of the satellite casino, the Chinese restaurant had also closed. Of course, this hotel is not located in any of the six historical zones defined by the SAR Government. The employees at the satellite casino received new job offers, but what happened to the staff at the Chinese restaurant, who pays attention to their future? I am concerned that while the “diversification of 1+4 industries” is not yet mature, the drastic transformations at the core of Macau's economy will have an impact on the economic structure. Although the unemployment rate is apparently low, the reality of the employment situation deserves attention. Chief Executive Sam Hou Fai encouraged young people to leave their comfort zone and venture to the Guangdong-Hong Kong-Macao Greater Bay Area, however, the Greater Bay Area faces its own challenges. Young people from Macau who study outside the city choose to stay there and each one will have their own reasons. The SAR Government claims that it wants to attract talented foreigners to Macau, while encouraging our young people to leave the city, which seems contradictory. Former deputy Lam U Tao even expressed concern about the number of non-resident teachers in Macau, proposing the creation of a mechanism that would lead more than 100,000 non-resident workers to leave the city and “return job vacancies to local workers”. Unfortunately, although Lam passed the government assessment in the 2021 Legislative Assembly elections, he was disqualified for the 2025 elections. When will the “window to democracy” be opened so that residents can breathe fresh air? Looking doesn't kill hunger. I recently visited the renovated Taipa Market and saw that the pedestrian traffic areas are still insufficient. Vegetable, meat and seafood vendors were waiting for customers, in stark contrast to the hustle and bustle of Gongbei Market in Zhuhai. The doors and windows of the Taipa Market were open, but the air (the clientele) was insufficient. Sellers have tried hard, but the results continue to be disappointing. Why does this happen? Is it useful to turn off lights at night and turn them on during the day? I believe that the main people responsible for the SAR Government should leave their comfort zones. At the end of the afternoon, they should take public transport and get off at the stop in front of the Public Administration Building on Rua do Campo and experience the warm feeling of sharing the journey with other passengers. They should also try to cross the border on foot at the Portas do Cerco Border Post and the Qingmao Border Post, in the morning and late afternoon, witnessing the magnificent spectacle of “integration in the Great Bay”. With numerous advertisements saying “excellent store for rent” in various areas of Macau, how can the lights be on after they have been turned off? The development of an urban area and the formation of a commercial area cannot be achieved simply by turning on the lights, they require collective wisdom.

item.title: Venezuela and the New World Geopolitics
item.description: “Power reshapes the world not only through action, but through the precedents it gives to create.” – Henry Kissinger The United States' military intervention in Venezuela, on January 3, 2026, cannot be understood simply as a gesture of strength in a weakened country but must be read as an event that exposes the structural tension between sovereignty, responsibility and power in a world in transition. The operation, carried out with almost surgical precision, was limited to extracting Nicolás Maduro and Cilia Flores from Caracas and transporting them to New York, where they face a judicial process that quickly went beyond the criminal sphere to become a political, philosophical and legal phenomenon of global reach. The absence of territorial occupation, provisional administration or any attempt to reorganize the Venezuelan State for now reveals a doctrine that breaks with the interventionist paradigm of the beginning of the 21st century in which the United States does not seek to rebuild countries, only to neutralize sources of threat, leaving behind the political void that inevitably forms when a regime loses its center of gravity. This void was filled by Delcy Rodríguez, whose rise is not the result of any popular mandate, but of the inertia of a state machine that, long ago, stopped functioning as a republican institution and began to operate as an instrument of survival for an exhausted political project. Its legitimacy is purely mechanical, derived from Chavismo's internal line of succession, and not from the will expressed at the polls, which in 2024 gave Edmundo González Urrutia a mandate that he never exercised. Maduro's extraction did not dissolve the networks that supported the regime; he just removed the figure that gave them faces. Delcy inherited a corroded state, but functional enough to maintain the appearance of normality, while the underground military, economic and criminal structures continue to operate with the same logic that transformed Venezuela into a narco state. The trial in New York became a legal laboratory that challenges traditional categories of international law. The invocation of universal jurisdiction for transnational crimes committed by a head of state, albeit illegitimate, captured by military means puts into tension principles that, for decades, seemed unquestionable. Sovereign immunity, designed to protect the stability of international relations, confronts the idea that certain crimes, due to their nature, cannot be shielded by functional prerogatives. The defense will argue that the capture violates fundamental norms, while the prosecution will maintain that the seriousness of the alleged facts justifies the exception. The court will become the stage for a dispute that goes beyond the individual destiny of the accused and touches on the very balance between sovereignty, responsibility and power. The global transmission of the process will amplify every gesture and word, converting the trial into a political event that redefines conceptual boundaries. The legal discussion inevitably refers to historical precedents that shaped the contemporary understanding of individual criminal responsibility. The trial of Eichmann, captured in Buenos Aires and taken to Jerusalem in 1961, is often cited as an example that extraterritorial capture, although controversial, does not necessarily invalidate the legitimacy of the process. The doctrine that emerged from that case with the idea that certain crimes are so serious that they transcend borders is echoed in the current debate. However, the comparison has limits as Eichmann was a fugitive without official status, while Maduro was head of state at the time of his capture, which reactivates the discussion about functional and personal immunities. The Pinochet case, partially tried in the United Kingdom, introduced another fissure in the traditional legal edifice by admitting that crimes of torture cannot be protected by sovereign immunity. International jurisprudence has evolved since then, but remains fragmented, oscillating between the defense of sovereignty and the affirmation of an international legal order that holds individuals accountable regardless of their position. Venezuela, however, remains suspended between two periods. The democratic opposition, although legitimized by the vote, remains far from exercising power. Edmundo González Urrutia, exiled in Spain, became a symbol of a legitimacy that exists internationally, but not in the territory he should govern. María Corina Machado, reappeared after the fall of Maduro, regained internal protagonism, but faces a structural obstacle, that the formal State is only the visible surface of a parallel system, where criminal networks, military interests and informal alliances shape political reality. The opposition has legitimacy, but does not control the territory; it has international support, but it does not have the coercive instruments that define effective power. The Venezuelan military structure, far from being dismantled by the American operation, remains fragmented and permeated by contradictory loyalties. Maduro's extraction neutralized only the closest circle, leaving intact a hierarchy eroded by decades of politicization, corruption and involvement in illicit economies. Many senior officers maintain links with networks that operate outside the legality, while intermediate sectors seek to reposition themselves to guarantee their own survival. The absence of broader institutional intervention allowed the narco state to continue to function, now under the leadership of Delcy Rodríguez, who is trying to reorganize Chavismo without its historical leader, preserving the informal mechanisms that guarantee the continuity of power. The Venezuelan economy, devastated by years of mismanagement and hyperinflation, remains in a state of structural collapse. PDVSA, once a symbol of prosperity, operates far below its capacity, and the global fall in oil prices further reduces financial room for maneuver. Maduro's extraction did not change this reality. Without deep reforms, political transition and international trust, the economy remains paralyzed. The criminalization of the political economy impedes any sustainable recovery, as illicit networks capture revenues, distort incentives, and block any attempt at institutional reconstruction. Venezuela has become an extreme case of a state where the formal economy is just a residual fragment of a system dominated by parallel circuits. The Portuguese community, one of the largest Portuguese-speaking diasporas outside Europe, lives in an environment of permanent uncertainty. Political instability, the lack of reforms and the continuity of criminal networks create significant risks, but also opportunities if a minimum of predictability emerges. Portugal can play a relevant role through reinforced consular protection and economic diplomacy, but any initiative will depend on the country's internal developments. At the international level, the American operation reinforced the tendency to replace multilateralism with surgical unilateral actions. The lack of coordination with international organizations weakened traditional alliances and intensified rivalries with emerging powers, in a context in which Russia and China had responded with military demonstrations in the Caribbean and the Persian Gulf to signal that they contest the power projection of the United States and intend to preserve their influence in a hemisphere historically sensitive to external intervention. Venezuela has thus become a microcosm of the new global order; a space where strategic disputes, legal tensions and conflicts of legitimacy intersect. The country's future will depend on the interaction between internal and external factors, now profoundly changed by Delcy Rodríguez's cooperation with Washington and the increasing control of the oil sector by the Americans. Between 2026 and 2030, four main trajectories can be outlined. The first is the consolidation under the tutelage of Delcy Rodríguez, which not only represents the continuity of Chavismo, but rather the adaptation of the regime to a new geopolitical reality. Cooperation with the United States transforms Chavismo into a partially domesticated system, where the narco state continues to operate, but within externally imposed limits. Stability becomes dependent on American tolerance, the relative discipline of the Armed Forces and the regime's ability to redistribute oil rents under implicit surveillance. It is not a sovereign stability, but a stability under guardianship, in which Caracas governs while Washington defines the perimeter of the possible. The second trajectory is the agreed transition, now reconfigured by the centrality of oil. It is no longer just a controlled exit in exchange for personal guarantees for sectors of Chavismo, but a political-energy negotiation in which Washington accepts a gradual opening and institutional recomposition as long as it maintains decisive influence over the oil sector. Delcy becomes the bridge between the system and the transition, offering Americans energy predictability and Chavismo guarantees of partial survival. Political change would be limited but real, and would allow controlled pluralism under international supervision. The third trajectory is the implosion of the system, now aggravated by oil cooperation itself. Shared management of the energy sector could deepen internal fissures, especially between the military, criminal networks and ideological factions that see approaching the United States as betrayal. Economic deterioration, inequality in the redistribution of income and competition for resources under external supervision can accelerate the fragmentation of the State, creating enclaves of autonomous power and multiplying armed actors. In this scenario, energy protection does not prevent implosion; amplified, by introducing new reasons for dispute and distrust. The fourth trajectory is the possibility of a second American intervention, now more plausible precisely because oil cooperation creates an evaluation criterion. If, despite energy control, Chavismo reorganized under Delcy continues to operate as a narco state and no substantive political transformation occurs, Washington may conclude that the extraction of Maduro was insufficient. The new intervention would not necessarily imply territorial occupation, but could take surgical forms such as the neutralization of specific military actors, blocking of illicit financial networks, additional operations against security structures or even a multinational intervention legitimized by extreme humanitarian collapse. The mere existence of this hypothesis weakens the first trajectory, as Delcy's consolidation would only be sustainable in an international environment willing to tolerate the continuity of Chavismo, which is becoming increasingly less likely. Thus, Venezuela remains in a political and institutional limbo without Maduro, but with Chavismo; with functional administration, but without legitimacy; with oil cooperation with the United States, but without full sovereignty. Maduro's extraction and oil co-management did not end the cycle; they just reshaped the battlefield. Reconstruction will require inclusive dialogue, profound reform and an international commitment to legality. Until then, the country remains suspended between the end of a regime that does not exist and the impossibility of a future that has not yet begun.

item.title: Homo Sapiens versus “Goldilocks Conditions”
item.description: Around 13.8 billion years ago, what is known as the “big bang” occurred. From this great explosion an expanding universe emerged, which is essentially made up of dark energy, dark matter, gases, dust, planets and stars. These grouped together to form galaxies, in one of which, the Milky Way, our planet is located, fortunately very far away, around 25,800 light years, from the black hole that occupies the central area. By happy chance, during the evolution of the universe, planet Earth, which was formed about 4.5 billion years ago, occupied an ideal position to create the conditions for life to emerge. The first signs of life are due to the existence of oxygen in the atmosphere and hydrosphere, and to the Earth orbiting around the Sun at a distance that allows it to receive radiation whose intensity can be considered neither excessive nor lacking. Thus, the first species of beings emerged that evolved, giving rise to hundreds of thousands of other species that adapted to climate variations. The climate system has, however, undergone changes due to several factors, namely cosmic and volcanic in origin. Cosmic factors include the variation in solar activity and the Milankovitch cycles, which consist of changes in the orbit around the Sun, related to the eccentricity, obliquity and oscillation of the Earth's axis. The action of these and other factors resulted in climate changes, including those that caused the ice ages and interglacials. The conditions favorable to the existence of life on our planet are commonly referred to, in circles related to astronomy and astrobiology, as “Goldilocks conditions”, which could be translated as “golden snail conditions”, so called by analogy with the children's story “Goldilocks and the three bears”, very popular in English-speaking countries, written by Robert Southey (1774-1843). In this story, a girl with golden curls always chose the middle ground as the best option among the possibilities that came across her throughout her mischief. For example, between three plates of porridge, one very hot, one very cold and one lukewarm, I would choose the lukewarm one, or between three beds I would prefer the one that was neither too hard nor too soft, but moderately soft. When applied to astronomy, this concept metaphorically refers to a habitable zone in the universe. In reality, even though there may be other planets with conditions similar to those on Earth, it will not be possible, at least in the next few decades, to reach them and create the conditions so that our civilization can survive in the event of a collapse of living conditions on our planet. We must therefore take care of the Earth's climate system. Otherwise, mass extinctions of species could occur. This has already happened five times and there are those who claim that we are facing the sixth extinction, due to human activities, with special emphasis on climate change, pollution, destruction of habitats and unrestrained exploitation of natural resources. Currently, no significant trend has been detected regarding cosmic factors that could alter these “Goldilocks conditions”. However, when it comes to human behavior, the reality is that, if we do not curb the indiscriminate use of fossil fuels, we are causing a significant increase in global warming. Humanity is not ensuring that these conditions persist, given that our planet has been warming since the beginning of the industrial era, at a rate never observed before, which causes the degradation of the various components of the climate system. And the near future does not look bright, as the country that emits the most greenhouse gases has at its head an irresponsible government that continues to ignore the warnings of institutions responsible for monitoring climate change and ensuring the sustainability of our planet. Worse than that, it has been taking measures contrary to these recommendations, such as, for example, withdrawing from the Paris Agreement, dismissing scientists from organizations that deal with the atmosphere and oceans, or cutting funding to universities where research related to climate change is carried out. Finally, a list of measures that could contribute to the deterioration of the climate system, thus posing a threat to life on our planet. The worst thing is that, as the former Secretary-General of the United Nations, Kofi Annan, stated, “there is no planet B”. But, one might ask, «what does all this have to do with these “Goldilocks conditions”?». In reality, the changes that the climate has undergone and which are estimated to have caused, in the last four hundred and fifty million years, some of the five mass extinctions of living beings, took place over thousands of years. It is commonly accepted by paleontologists and paleoclimatologists that the greater or lesser concentration of carbon dioxide was one of the causes of climate change that was the basis for most mass extinctions. Only one of the great extinctions, that of dinosaurs and other species of megafauna, is not directly related to climate, but rather due to the impact of an asteroid with Earth, around 66 million years ago. The big difference between the climate changes of thousands of years ago and the changes that the climate is currently undergoing is the fact that those changes occurred slowly, over thousands of years, while the current ones have only been occurring since the beginning of the industrial revolution, that is, for around two and a half hundred years. According to cosmologist Stephen Hawking (1942–2018), “Like Goldilocks, the development of intelligent life requires that planetary temperatures be ‘just right'”. Inspired by this statement from someone who has studied the evolution of the universe in depth, we can only contribute to ensuring that these “Goldilocks conditions” continue to be fulfilled. Luis Queirós (1) will certainly forgive me for using the calculations contained in his book “Humanity and the Future” to highlight how recent the appearance of Homo sapiens is, in relation to the appearance of the first signs of life, between 3 billion and 4 billion years ago. Abandoning periods on a geological scale, which are difficult to grasp, and resorting to matching an intermediate value, for example 3.6 billion years, to 40 hours, Homo sapiens would have appeared only in the last fifteen seconds. Let me add that, maintaining this correspondence, the approximately 250 years since the industrial revolution correspond to 0.012 seconds. Let us hope that in the next few thousandths of a second Homo sapiens will curb the use of fossil fuels and carry out an effective energy transition, taking measures to halt and reverse global warming, ensuring that “Goldilocks conditions” continue to protect us. (Meteorologist) (1) Luis Queirós – author of “The World in Transition” and “Humanity and the Future”. Founder of the Marktest Group, a pioneering entity in market research in Portugal. He established the “Fundação Vox Populi” and created the blog “Transição”.

item.title: Christmas isn't sexy for everyone
item.description: I found interesting studies on how libido fluctuates among people around the holidays. There are those who have the conditions to feel a lot of sexual desire and spend the holidays in intimate moments of passion, and there are those – which I believe is the majority – feel a total disconnection with their libido. The Christmas films that, thanks to streaming platforms, proliferate by the hundreds every year, suggest that people should be more romantic and affectionate, and sex should follow this trend. The discrepancy in libido, which could point to inter-individual differences, also suggests that desire responds to the context in which we are inserted. There is a study that shows that parties correspond to a spike in interest in sex, not only by analyzing online discussions/searches, but also by the spike in births essentially 9 months later. Sexuality somehow reacts to the symbolic aspects that parties carry, through the desire for closeness and contact. However, this will not be the universal experience. It is also reported that, in the same Christmas context, we have people with high sexual desire, and others with low sexual desire. Most likely the answer to the discrepancy lies in the way the festivities are viewed. On the one hand, it is a time of deceleration, which increases the erotic potential. Research in sexual psychology repeatedly shows that lower stress states are associated with higher levels of sexual arousal and satisfaction. When the nervous system leaves “survival” mode, desire has room to reappear. It is also a time that activates feelings of nostalgia, which can increase feelings of connection and vitality — emotional states that facilitate intimacy and desire. On the other hand, the festivities also carry dynamics, through memories and melancholy, which can be hard and heavy. Family conflicts, loneliness, anxiety, unfulfilled expectations: for many people, Christmas is not an emotional refuge but a relational minefield. And sexual desire is highly sensitive to these internal states. Psychological stress and emotional fatigue are consistently associated with decreased libido and sexual responsiveness. A small mention can also be made of alcohol, that sexual shaper, omnipresent at parties. A drink or two can reduce inhibitions and increase subjective feelings of desire or closeness. But this effect is fragile. Larger amounts impair physiological arousal and sexual response. The result, for many people, is a short spike in desire followed by tiredness, disconnection or frustration — a common dynamic during the festive season. All this to say that the same trigger – Christmas and its festivities – brings some people closer to their libido, and takes it away from others. Christmas, therefore, amplifies what is already within us. For those who associate this time with security, rest and emotional connection, the body responds with more erotic openness. For those who experience Christmas as stress, exposure or emotional regression, desire tends to recede. The problem is not in libido, but in expectations. The cultural idea that Christmas should be a sexy, romantic and intimate time creates pressure that does little to help. Desire does not respond well to symbolic imperatives or emotional calendars. It responds to human conditions: rest, security, space or absence of obligation. Accepting that Christmas can be exciting for some and completely desexualizing for others, or both at different times, is a more honest and healthy way of looking at human sexuality. Not all intimacy needs to culminate in sex. And if Christmas is devoid of desire, wait until January.

item.title: Macau Tower | Show celebrates Sino-Portuguese culture
item.description: A new theatrical show takes the stage tomorrow to explore how 500 years of contact between Portuguese and Chinese cultures gave Macau “a unique identity”. In the third edition of the “Macasaphis” series, the experimental theater group Frost Ice Snow Creative brings together music, theater, fashion, oral stories and stand-up comedy in the Macau Tower auditorium. The director, Sileas Ko Weng Si, told Lusa yesterday that, after a two-year break due to lack of funding, the group decided to return with the theme “Sino-Portuguese culture”. "Sino-Portuguese culture is everywhere, but we don't even realize it anymore. People often get confused, without understanding how it influences our lives", explained Sileas Ko. The first edition of “Macasahpis”, in 2022, had already been dedicated to particular elements of the region. “The presence of the Chinese and Portuguese languages, the historical monuments, the fact that we have the largest number of holidays in the world, both Buddhist and Catholic,” said Ko. Portuguese is one of the two official languages ​​of Macau, at least during the first 50 years of the new semi-autonomous Chinese region, according to the bilateral agreement that allowed the transition of administration in December 1999. The 2023 edition had as guests Tuna Macaense, a musical group from the Eurasian community, made up mainly of Portuguese descendants, who play songs in the Creole dialect, Patuá. But this time the group decided to go further and celebrate how Portuguese influence is also felt among the Chinese in Macau, the show's producer, Casta Lai Chit, told Lusa. “Maybe people still feel some shame in defining our culture and identity, because we are Chinese, but we are not the same as others”, explained Casta Lai, who has Portuguese nationality. “People are proud of Macau’s culture, but they have some shame in showing it”, lamented Sileas Ko. "Sino-Portuguese culture makes our city even more special. Without it, there would only be casinos", he added. Cultural power With an area of ​​just 33 square kilometers and less than 680,000 inhabitants, Macau “is a tiny fish” in the context of China, with a population of 1.4 billion, Casta Lai highlighted. “If it weren’t for Sino-Portuguese culture, Macau wouldn’t be important at all,” argued the producer. The show includes a part in which, in a humorous way, the population of Macau is treated as “an endangered species” and not just because the city has the lowest birth rate in the world, said Sileas Ko. Casta Lai warned that "maybe after 50 years the culture will be different. If that happens, maybe people will look around and miss what was lost."

item.title: First retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida in Asia opens on the 23rd
item.description: The Macau Museum of Art (MAM) will open the first retrospective of Portuguese artist Helena Almeida (1934-2018) in Asia on January 23, announced one of the exhibition's curators. The exhibition “Helena Almeida: I'm Here – Presença and Resonance” is “one of the most comprehensive ever presented” and will be on display until April 26, Margarida Saraiva said on social media. The MAM curator stated that the retrospective will be divided into five sections, “chronologically and thematically”, including one dedicated to the first paintings and another to “the body as sculpture and the dialogue between bodies”. Saraiva named Helena Almeida as “one of the most relevant Portuguese and European artists of her generation”, who “transformed the act of self-representation into an intense exploration of the body, space, resilience and impermanence”. “His performative gestures — captured only through the lens of his studio — continue to challenge and expand the limits of painting, drawing and photography,” explained the curator. “This exhibition is simultaneously a tribute to Helena Almeida’s extraordinary legacy and an affirmation of the power of curatorial collaboration between cultures”, argued Saraiva. The retrospective's main curator is Delfim Sardo, professor at the University of Coimbra and author of the book “Helena Almeida, Pés no Chão, Cabeça no Céu”, and the Chinese Song Zhen as co-curator. Divide by two In December, the Macau Cultural Institute indicated in a statement that the exhibition will bring together around 42 sets made up of 190 pieces by the Portuguese artist. Another part of the exhibition, “Resonância – Corpo. Objecto. Reflexão”, was opened on December 19, with pieces by six artists from Macau and mainland China, invited to interact with the work of Helena Almeida. Born in Lisbon in 1934, Helena Almeida created, from the 1960s onwards, a multifaceted work, giving rise to a work that stood out for its self-representation, reflecting on the tension relationships between the body, space and the work. He used his body as a support and creative object, using painting, photography, engraving, installation and video. Helena Almeida studied painting at the Escola Superior de Belas-Artes in Lisbon, beginning to exhibit individually in 1967, at Galeria Buchholz. The artist represented Portugal at the Venice Biennale on two occasions: in 1982 and 2005, and in 2004 she participated in the Sydney Biennale, with her work being exhibited in individual and collective exhibitions in national and international museums and galleries. In 2015, he presented a traveling solo exhibition Corpus at Fundação de Serralves (2015), in Porto, in Paris (2016), in Brussels (2016) and Valencia (2017). In 2017, he also presented a solo exhibition “Work is never finished” at the Art Institute, in Chicago, in the United States. His work is present in Portuguese and international collections such as: Berardo Collection, Lisbon; Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, Lisbon; Serralves Foundation, Porto; Hara Museum of Contemporary Art, Tokyo; Barcelona Museum of Contemporary Art; Museo Nacional Centro de Arte Reina Sofía, Madrid; MUDAM – Musée d’Art Moderne Grand-Duc Jean, Luxembourg; Tate Modern, London.

item.title: Boi Warehouse | Three artists present visions of Macau on display
item.description: “Land and Sea” is the new exhibition hosted by Armazém do Boi and which opens to the public tomorrow. Featuring works by David Fank, this exhibition is the result of the artist's personal experiences in the Greater Bay Area, including cities such as Macau, Zhuhai and Guangzhou. Also noteworthy are the exhibitions by Yuan Zeqiang and Fan Xianxin A new exhibition opens tomorrow at Armazém do Boi. It is “Land and Sea”, written by David Fank, and which can be seen until February. According to a note from Armazém do Boi, the exhibition is divided into two main installations, with the themes of “Earth” and “Sea”, revealing an “exhibition space built like a room where blue and green meet, serving as the artist’s version of a ‘map'” It is in this type of map that the artist's “personal travel experiences” through the Greater Bay Area are shown, namely in places such as Macau, Zhuhai and Guangzhou, without forgetting Beijing. The public can see “an interpretation of these diverse geographic perspectives”, in which David Fank creates “actions such as walks, photography and objects that anchor and generate this map”. “These crystallize in his understanding of the meanings behind these spaces and, naturally, in the change of these meanings – the artist’s gaze and associations, in a sense as an ‘outsider’, thus become manifest”, he further explains. Tomorrow, Wang Jing will give an introduction to the exhibition, starting at 4pm, with “Land and Sea” being the result of an artistic residency carried out by David Fank at Armazém do Boi, namely with the “Artistic Residency Program 3+0/1+1 (Macau / Project 2025)”. David Fank was born in 1984, has a degree and master's degree from the Higher School of Fine Arts in Paris and also a doctorate from the Central Academy of Fine Arts in Beijing, China. He works mainly with photography, installation and sculpture. The stone as origin Another exhibition that can also be seen at Armazém do Boi starting tomorrow is “Seak Kam Tong”, by Yuan Zeqiang, curated by Hu Bin. This exhibition is also the result of the same artistic residency program that hosted the work of David Fank. Here, Yuan Zeqiang establishes a relationship between art and stone, and in turn with the territory itself. “The relationship with stone begins the moment you enter Macau: under your feet, you have a mosaic stone floor”, which includes the Portuguese sidewalk, in addition to “the Temple of A-Má was built on a rocky hill, having become a place where residents and visitors turn for spiritual support”. This exhibition presents “three-dimensional collages that reveal the dualities and truths of modern life”, where Yuan Zeqiang explores the different dimensions, perspectives and meanings of stones in a territory like Macau. "The Portuguese sidewalk, made of fragmented stone, in Macau is a legacy of Portuguese colonial history, and this homogeneous material environment seems to reflect the clash and fusion of multiple cultures in the city. In everyday life, stone appears as a ubiquitous landscape element, something particularly evident in Macau", said Yuan Zeqiang, quoted in the same note. Relationship with the sea Still at Armazém do Boi, the public can see “Standing Wave Manifold”, by Fan Xianxin, curated by Sun Xiaoyu, which explores Macau's relationship with water and the way in which the territory was built with permanent mutations. "'Sea-Mirror' is one of the many names that Macau has had throughout its history. This image refers to a state of immobilization located in a specific time and space. In this city surrounded by water, the border between water and land has been continuously reconstructed since the 19th century to the present day, and the evolution of denominations has occurred together with the changing trajectories of systems, power and identity", of the territory itself, explains a note about the exhibition. The artist, who also completed a period of artistic residency at Armazém do Boi, analyzes Macau “from observations and travels”, trying to “understand how systems, landscapes and Feng Shui act together in shaping our concrete and detailed daily lives”. This exhibition presents concepts such as “standing waves” and “varieties” that are not only physical, but reveal “dynamic equilibrium structures that are formed with the interference of two waves that go in opposite directions, but that constitute a method to interpret the modernization process in Macau”. In this way, we try to understand “the complex totality that is woven by countless fragments, all of them interconnected”. Thus, “Standing Wave Manifold” focuses on the search for investigation “of a ‘mobility’ structure built from ‘movement'”, it is described.

item.title: Creative Macao | Exhibition “Flow”, by Alice Costa, presented today
item.description: Creative Macau presents a new exhibition to the public today. This is “Flow”, by local artist Alice Costa (Lili), a series of works that presents “organic forms and fluid lines that capture the spontaneity of nature”. In this exhibition, the artist “employs techniques such as impasto, splashes and layers, to create textured surfaces that invite visual and tactile involvement”, reads the note released by the gallery. Alice Costa (Lilli) is a Macau-based painter whose work explores the essence of nature through form, texture and emotion. Born in Macau to a Portuguese father and a Chinese mother, Alice Costa initially pursued a career in Law, graduating from the University of Macau in 1994 and serving as a judge at the Court of First Instance from 1997 onwards. However, “a deep creative vocation led her to painting three years ago”, now dedicating herself completely to the abstract style of painting. Also according to Creative Macau, the artist's work “is a dialogue between the structured and the organic, translating the rhythms of the natural world, such as forests, oceans, storms and light, into non-representational forms”. "Alice Costa's paintings are sensory experiences. They ask the viewer not to recognize, but to feel, to connect with the invisible emotions and primitive rhythms within the chaos and serenity of nature", he further explains.

item.title: IPIM | 13 plan applications received for international companies
item.description: The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute announced that it received 13 applications in the first two months of a program launched to attract international companies to the Macao SAR. More than 500 companies requested information about the support plan The Macau Trade and Investment Promotion Institute (IPIM) revealed in a statement, released on Wednesday, that it had received 13 applications for the “Plan for Economic Development within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau”, opened in November last year. The entity added that it is analyzing applications to grant “financial support in accordance with budgetary capacity and public interest”. The Economic Development Plan within the scope of Support for the Establishment of the First Store in Macau provides support of up to one million patacas. To receive maximum support, companies must follow certain requirements, such as establishing themselves in NAPE, Areia Preta, Iao Hon, San Kio area, Praia do Manduco, Fai Chi Kei, Doca do Lam Mau, Bairro de Tamagnini Barbosa or Ilha Verde. Furthermore, they must have a minimum area, as well as a certain number of full-time local employees. IPIM also highlighted that more than 500 companies requested information about the program, which was launched on November 1st. The plan lasts three years and has six application phases, the first of which runs until the end of January. At the end of November, the institute's president, Che Weng Keong, said in the Legislative Assembly that among the companies that requested more information about the plan were “brands from Portugal”. IPIM recalled that it “took the initiative” to contact entities in mainland China, Southeast Asia and Portuguese and Spanish speaking countries. Harvest fruits The program, which aims to “enrich the tourist charm of Macau and boost the community economy”, was presented in Lisbon and Porto, at the beginning of October, by IPIM officials, who then also held presentations in neighboring Spain, in Madrid and Barcelona. IPIM promised to continue publicizing the plan, including through participation in convention and exhibition events, “encouraging cooperation between Macau companies and foreign brands, including those from Portuguese-speaking countries”.

item.title: Game | Seaport forecasts 19% revenue growth in January
item.description: The basis of comparison helps, but Macau's main industry continues to expand month after month. The most recent report from Seaport Research Partners predicts that revenues will increase by 14 percent annually by March Financial services firm Seaport Research Partners predicts 19 percent annual gaming revenue growth in January, according to the institution's most recent report. At a quarterly level, revenues can increase by around 14 percent. “Our estimate for January points to an increase of 19 percent compared to the previous year (4 percent more compared to the previous month), with the growth rate helped by an easy comparison [compared to the 2025 value]”, can be read in the report by analyst Vitaly Umansky, cited by the GGR Asia portal. In January 2025, the game's gross revenue was 18.3 billion patacas, the lowest value of the entire year, which contributes to the highest relative growth. Despite the low basis for comparison, the 19 percent growth in revenue at the beginning of the year is seen by Umansky as a “solid” sign for the first quarter, in which gaming revenue is expected to expand by around 14 percent. It is recalled that in the first three months of 2025, revenue reached 57.7 billion patacas. “We estimate that the month started quite strong, possibly with revenues above 850 million patacas per day during the long weekend from January 1st to 4th”, the document states. Weakest December The forecast of 14 percent growth in the first quarter takes into account the fact that revenues slowed down in mid-December, which Seaport Research Partners believes is due to the fact that high rollers prefer to visit Macau to gamble between January and February. “We anticipate gross gaming revenues to grow more than 14 percent in the first quarter and seven percent in 2026,” Umansky said. “Growth in 2026 is supported by easy comparisons in the first half of the year and the continued easing of monetary flows and visa issuance”, he highlighted. Vitaly Umansky also said that if there is any unexpected increase in revenue in the mass market that the gaming industry's results could exceed the indicated forecast and that this increase would benefit concessionaires currently with greater capacity.

item.title: Wynn, MGM and Melco announce bonuses for workers
item.description: Gaming concessionaires Wynn Resorts and MGM China announced a bonus equivalent to one month of work that will cover between 95 and 98 percent of workers. The information was released yesterday through press releases, after the Galaxy dealership announced a similar measure on Tuesday. As far as Wynn Macau is concerned, the bonus will cover 98 percent of the current 11,552 eligible employees, as “recognition of the exceptional contributions of all team members over the last year”. “We are truly grateful for the efforts and contributions of our team members over the past year and are pleased to announce a special grant in recognition of their hard work,” said Linda Chen, Vice President and CEO of Wynn Macau. “This year we celebrate the important milestone of our 20th anniversary in Macau — not only an achievement for Wynn, but also a testament to the dedication of every member of our team,” he added. General trends In the case of MGM, the bonus will cover 95 percent of workers, as “recognition for their dedication and contributions throughout 2025”. The amount will begin to be paid from the 21st of this month. “Reflecting on 2025, we are moving forward with a new chapter, continually optimizing our innovative products and service experiences, achieving steady progress in the development of our business – all thanks to the dedication and hard work of our team,” said Pansy Ho, president and CEO of MGM China in a statement. "Looking to the future, MGM will continue to enhance its strengths, with an unwavering focus on our guests. Guided by the philosophy of 'Originality + Innovation', we will remain dedicated to contributing to the positioning of Macau as a world-class tourism and leisure center, through the continuous introduction of more diverse tourism offerings", he stressed. Finally, Melco Resorts also announced a bonus for “eligible workers”, but the proportion of the workforce covered was not indicated. "The discretionary bonus payment recognizes the dedication and support of our colleagues over the past year. We sincerely appreciate their loyalty and commitment to consistently exceeding guest expectations, which together helps the company maintain and enhance its leadership position in the entertainment and hospitality industry," said Lawrence Ho, group president.

item.title: Damn | Woman arrested for heroin trafficking
item.description: A 43-year-old woman was arrested after being intercepted with 0.83 grams of heroin, valued at MOP1,000, while returning from Hong Kong. The case was revealed yesterday by the Judiciary Police and the investigation was based on a complaint. According to the PJ's version, the woman is an unemployed local resident, who had made several trips between Macau and Hong Kong with the purpose of trafficking and consuming drugs. In addition to the drugs, authorities seized syringes, packages for storing drugs and other materials for consumption. A search of the woman's house, in Coloane, also resulted in the seizure of other materials used to consume narcotics. The detainee was also tested for urine, which tested positive for drug consumption. The case was handed over to the Public Ministry (MP). Illegal exchanges | Two cases lead to the seizure of 47,900 HK dollars Authorities seized 47,900 Hong Kong dollars worth of gambling chips, which they believed were used in illegal money exchanges. The seizure resulted from two different cases, carried out by the Judiciary Police and the Public Security Police Corps. The first situation involved a 40-year-old man from the Interior, caught red-handed exchanging money with a player. The latter confessed that he had previously exchanged 300 renminbi for 300 Hong Kong dollars in tokens, which led to the first arrest and seizure of 28,500,000 Hong Kong dollars, in the possession of the suspected criminal. In turn, the first detainee claimed to have made profits from exchanging money worth 7,000 Hong Kong dollars. The second detainee, also at the casino, was also intercepted in the act. The individual is also from the Interior and, in addition to an attempt to exchange 6,000 Hong Kong dollars for 6,000 renminbis, he had 19,400,000 Hong Kong dollars in his possession.

item.title: Game | Malaysian company gives up letter factory in Macau
item.description: Malaysian company Mega Fortris Bhd has scrapped plans to open a playing card factory in Macau due to difficulties in finding space and high rents. However, a warehouse will be established in Macau to supply local customers Malaysian company Mega Fortris Bhd has abandoned plans to build a factory in Macau to produce playing cards. The company specializing in security seals had planned to use the funds raised through an initial public offering (IPO) to invest in the manufacturing unit in Macau, a plan that was outlined in late 2024. At that time, Mega Fortris Bhd announced plans for two manufacturing units for printing playing cards in Macau and Malaysia, an investment of around US$24.5 million. The amount would be invested in purchasing the installation of specialized machinery and equipment. The Macau unit would be in charge of a subcontracted company, whose mission would be to find a location and adapt it for production processes, also responsible for obtaining licenses and authorizations to operate in the Macao SAR, according to the Inside Asian Gaming portal. The decision to give up the factory in Macau was justified, in a note sent to shareholders, with the need to “reevaluate the business strategy” in the playing cards chapter. The company indicated that it had “encountered difficulties in finding suitable industrial facilities in Macau” that would meet the size and weight requirements” needed for the production line. Furthermore, the company revealed that it had “observed an increase in rental costs in Macau, which could result in higher fees charged by the subcontractor company”, according to the GGR Asia portal. Expected dates The manufacturing unit in Malaysia is scheduled to begin operations in the last quarter of this year. In Macau, the group plans to set up a warehouse that provides gaming cards and sealed safety boxes to Macao SAR customers. According to the company's forecasts, the warehouse will begin operations in the second quarter of 2027. The Macau facility will also be equipped with a tracking software system for game card lockboxes, and equipment to destroy cards after use.

item.title: Great Bay | New association created with a focus on AI
item.description: A new association has just been created to develop the area of ​​artificial intelligence (AI) in the Greater Bay Area. According to the statutes published yesterday in the Official Gazette (BO), the Artificial Intelligence Development Association of the Greater Bay Area (Macau) aims to “promote the innovative development of AI technologies and their local application, covering key areas such as commerce, finance, scientific research, professional training and early childhood, primary and secondary education”. Another of the entity's objectives is the “training of local technical talents and the development of the applications ecosystem, comprehensively increasing the competitiveness of Macau's smart industries”. The aim is also to “bring together forces from all sectors of society, responding actively to the national strategies of ‘a country strong in science and technology'”. The new association also wants to “transform the development of AI into an essential engine for the adequate diversification of Macau’s economy, promoting industrial modernization, innovative transformation and sustainable development”. To achieve these ends, the aim is to “organize academic lectures, seminars, exchanges and cooperation”.

item.title: Housing | Sales and prices with new drops at the beginning of December
item.description: The real estate market continues to crash. The average house price saw an annual reduction of 4.3 percent at the beginning of the last month of 2025, while sales fell 9.4 percent In the first half of December, the average housing price showed an annual decline of 4.3 percent to 78,838 patacas per square meter, according to data revealed by the Financial Services Directorate (DSF). The annual drop of 4.3 percent is due to the fact that at the beginning of December 2024 the average price per square meter was negotiated at 82,383 patacas per square meter, which represents a difference of 3,545 patacas per square meter in the space of one year. At the beginning of the previous month, the highest prices were charged in Taipa, with the average price standing at 86,163 patacas per square meter. Despite this, there was an annual reduction of 2.9 percent, given that in the same period last year the price was 88,762 patacas per square meter. In Coloane, housing was sold at an average price of 83,925 per square meter, a reduction of 22.7 percent compared to the same period last year, when the average price reached 102,976 patacas per square meter. Contrary to the general market trend, prices on the Macau Peninsula increased by 5 percent to 76,127 patacas per square meter, compared to 72,480 patacas per square meter in the same period last year. At a monthly level, between the beginning of November and the beginning of December 2025, the market showed an increase in prices of around 18.9 percent, given that at the beginning of November the average housing price had been 66,315 patacas per square meter. Fewer transactions The annual price reduction was accompanied by a decrease in the number of transactions. In the first half of December, there was an annual drop of 9.4 percent, from 96 transactions to 87. Despite the annual reduction, on the Macau Peninsula there were 14 more sales, with 67 registered in the most recent period, when in the same period there had been 53 transactions registered. However, in Taipa there were fewer transactions from 37 to 17, a difference of 20, and in Coloane a reduction from six to three transactions. When the comparison is made between the beginning of November and December 2025, the market showed a reduction of 31 transactions, from 118 to 87 purchases and sales.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. It says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom. Almost all 20th century art, with Surrealism at its head, made this mistake. The fallacy still exists despite the emergence of “irrationalism” and the consequent relativist currents that followed it having been consolidated everywhere. Essentially, much of what happened in the 20th century revolved around this clash between two paradigms: Rationalism versus Irationalism. Now, I see, we must save indeterminacy, chance, randomness from the terrible temptation of the cage of causalities. Holism, in its pathological form, may be reductionism that sets itself up as a new “eschatological narrative”. Is it “by chance” that holism emerges at a time when neo-liberalism and its cynical contempt for the human person is besieging everything, all freedoms, all acquired rights? Holistic awareness has brought a positive impact to greater ecological awareness, but followed with scholastic rigor, it stifles reality under the blanket of a determinism that is much more than uncomfortable: all great authoritarian ideologies are holistic. My friend will know how to combine her holistic and transpersonal belief with the freedom and responsibility that each moment asks of us — but how many will make the distinction, under a Law that explains and encompasses everything? How many will abandon themselves to what is? The awareness of the indeterminate brings tragic awareness, as the Greeks knew, but it also brings agency and the courage of decision. And we cannot give up on this. Furthermore, as Drummond shows in the poem “Quadrilha”, by Carlos Drummond de Andrade: «João loved Teresa who loved Raimundo/ who loved Maria who loved Joaquim who loved Lili/ who didn't love anyone./ João went to the United States, Teresa to the convent,/ Raimundo died of a disaster, Maria stayed with her aunt,/ Joaquim committed suicide and Lili married J. Pinto Fernandes/ who had not entered the story.» Real always runs outside the track, completely outside our concepts. That's what matters to us — a J. Pinto Fernandes emerges at the exact moment when we thought we had everything under control.

item.title: From Nobel and others
item.description: 9/10/22 When reading many people's reactions when this year's Nobel Prize for Literature was announced, I couldn't help but remember this comment from Jean-Pierre Siméon, in relation to another Nobel Prize: «An editor of a large national daily newspaper wrote five lines of indignation at the fact that the Nobel Prize for Literature had been awarded to Thomas Traströmer, a complete stranger. But unknown to whom? How did it not occur to this literary columnist, patented and paid to do his job, that his apparent ignorance was a matter of professional misconduct? Tranströmer had been translated into many languages, it was available in French.» There is always the chorus of those who wait for the Prize to be announced to complain about not having been invited to be on the jury, there is a subgroup of angry people who profess “I have never read it and I won’t even bother to read it”; It is a less than humble fauna, the one that inhabits social networks. I don't always know all the winners – I didn't know about the existence of Louise Glück, who I think is a great poet, or Olga Tokarczuk, for example – but this only brings me the comfort of knowing that the world is not a soap opera where everyone knows everyone else and the joy of recognizing that the yardstick of the world is not measured with my short measure and that, on the contrary, it gives me a new opportunity to face the unknown and learn from it. And perhaps the most stupid reaction was that of the intelligent man who wrote, But are there still people who read French?; simply confirming that today there is a new type of ignorance that is being raised with abandon: that of those who only read English. I would also prefer that, in French, Pascal Quignard, Linda Lê or even Sollers were awarded, or, among the new ones, Mathias Énard, but that does not detract from the dignity of Annie Ernaux's work (and it would have been enough to have written “Les Années”). There are books of hers that I like less, like the vulgar “Uma Paixão Simples”, but that happens with almost all authors, they have pivotal books and others that are like breaks in their itinerary. I recommend reading a beautiful book of interviews with her, “L’écriture comme un couteau”. 11/10/22 Yesterday an article appeared in the morning newspaper “Notícias”, in Maputo, reporting that the Pen Club Narrative Prize had been awarded to my wife, Teresa Noronha, for her soap opera “Tornado”, which had already won the Maria Velho da Costa Prize. The summary they made of the book does not even deserve comments, as it is pathetic, but what is important to highlight is the note of disqualification regarding its “Mozambicanness” when they call it Luso-Mozambican. It's not that it's inaccurate, but, for those who know the context, it's a touch naughty. Because finally, following the same logic, Adelino Timóteo should be called Tsonga-Mozambican, Álvaro Taruma Ronga-Mozambican, and Macua-Mozambican for writers from the north, etc., etc. Which doesn't appear to happen. At one point, in the novel, she writes: «Our color was never the dominant one. In colonial times we were not white, we were dressed in monhés, mugs of washed asses, the pejorative term to speak of a son of Goan and Portuguese. In the post-colonial period, I was not black and if, in Lisbon, they took me for Brazilian or Cape Verdean, in France they were lost in thought about where I was from and were surprised when they discovered that I was African. There I had to explain the wanderings of my DNA before settling in Mozambique. It took me a long time to accept that it was like that because yes, and that it was no curse that that was the case; on the contrary, I could even discover intense patterns of fantasy and freedom in this harlequin cloak that is our genealogy…” In modern-day Mozambique, it means being white… and that immediately takes precedence over what you do or what you are. It's sad, but as Naipaul warned, in these parts race is everything and people live as deeply immersed in it as, in other places, in religion. 12/10/22 Bruno Latour, an anthropologist who studied the sciences and their procedures and legitimations, law, technique and religions and who entertained himself by turning his back on the dogmas of the “moderns”, has died. For him, the place, the role of the specialist, was defined more by the perplexity he embodied than by the supposed truth that would sustain him. He proposed, as an alternative to the goodness of multiculturalism and its equivocal cliché “all different, all equal”, a return to “diplomacy”, given that this, precisely, does not start from the assumption that “we are unified because we share the same nature” but simply highlights that we “still do not share a common world”; It is necessary that we deal head-on with the “abyss of disagreement” that separates us, instead of trying to deceive it. And about politics he said, boldly: «Se se exige transparência ao político, matamo-lo; se alguém exige fidelidade ao que o outro era ou ao que diz, mata-o; se se exige uma relação mimética entre o que a multidão quer e o que diz o seu representante, mata-se a representação. Estes devem, portanto, por definição, trair, enganar, modificar, distorcer a palavra. Sem essa capacidade de dobrar a palavra e de trair, a linguagem política não existiria. I put forward the perfectly plausible hypothesis that political vocabulary will become as inaccessible as the religious language of the last twenty, three or fifty years.» (in “Un Monde Pluriel mais Commun”).
