Creio que nos fará falta para decifrar este mundo freneticamente complexo que nos coube.

item.title: Fuxi
item.description: O my friends, companions of these disastrous journeys through countries as old as the stars and the Moon, and as strange as the deepest interior of our wretched souls, what surprises still await us, what secret magics will we still have to overcome, what horrors will arise before our pupils dilated with astonishment and terror? Increasingly closer to our precarious existences, howls the monster of war, which threatens to merge humanity once and for all with the earth, incessantly traversed by the squalid specter of hunger and the invisible evil of ten thousand pestilences. Oh damned human, who believes you are superior to Nature itself, but then you reveal yourself, time and time again, incapable of simply ordering your existence and do not understand that you are possessed by fickle anger and are a slave to your own ambition! You are not satisfied with white jade or resplendent gold, there is no treasure that quenches your inextinguishable thirst for command over other men, animals and things; for eternal anguish dwells in you; in you the expelled serpents crawl; for you grows, powerful and impressive, the most fertile ivy of Evil! This is perhaps why on the Mount they call the White Deer, where one of the eight immortals on a sacred mount soared through the heavens towards Penglai, lives the fuxi, a bird whose shape resembles that of a rooster, although topped by a human head. What strange copulations, what monstrous embraces, what terrible procedures must have occurred to make the existence of this sinister animal possible? We don't know, but all it takes is for our exhausted mind to dare to come up with an answer, and then we feel our skin covered in horrendous goosebumps and our heart races in parade, like a wild horse whipped by the night whip of fear, unresponsive to reins and containment. Let men refrain from visiting Monte do Veado, because although there are riches capable of calming the wildest ambitions, if they have the unfortunate luck of catching a glimpse of a fuxi, it is certain that a war will soon break out and the cultivated fields will perish, because of it the tame animals will be beheaded, because of it the best young men of two generations will be sacrificed and the pride of the countries will be destroyed. The fuxi makes a sound reminiscent of its name. If you hear it, dark night or clear day, be on your way, because the path you are on is the surest path to misfortune!

item.title: Procrastinators Club
item.description: While rereading Easter, because of an article I'm preparing, I come across this excerpt, taken from “The Universal Man”: «Each man, morally, is one and absolute; but he has to live with attenuating his personality. (…) Coexistence is only possible between people reduced to a negative or hollow presence, which constantly gives way. Hence, the emptiness of society, an immense ghost made up of countless dead people. A superior man is antisocial or criminal. His destiny is prison and the desert”. I hesitate to think whether Pascoaes reflects here on the political-social conditions that muzzle, and, worse, in a sad country like Portugal in the middle of the Estado Novo (and the book is from 1931) where any possibilities of spontaneity and frankness in human relationships were restricted, or if it merely lends to the behavior of (oppressed) men a metaphysical framework, an “essence”, declared in the presumption of each being, in isolation, “one and absolute”. Sometimes, in addition to an excess of Spirituality (or Saudade), Pascoaes lacks the world. He is a great poet, but he is a poet who takes Ampoules-of-Great-Ideas and who therefore writes often trapped by a programmatic furor, ceasing to have pores; It is not uncommon for a glass to be erected between him and reality, the same glass that made him write in O Bailado, from 1921: «Everything is a ghost. There are only clouds, clouds of voices, clouds of souls, of afflictions and tragedies! Clouds and more clouds, appearances and more appearances! And a divine lightning that pierces them, the instantaneous Apparition that appears and throws us to the ground, dazzled!» Sometimes I felt like reminding him, as António Sérgio did, in the article “Regeneration and Tradition, Moral and Economy”, which he dedicated to Pascoaes: «Pascoais, Pascoais my dear friend: you are a pure, excellent and noble poet, but also a victim of this social environment, like us all: of this horrible isolation that you praise and I curse». «As a child, he stole two blackbirds», says Jacinto do Prado Coelho, he stole them from a nest, and he felt remorse for that all his life. The Person, few more mischiefs are known to him. Only in Álvaro de Campos does a hint of wickedness and obscenity emerge: «Ah, and the ordinary and dirty people, who always look the same,/ Who use swear words as usual words,/ Whose sons steal from grocery store doors/ And whose daughters at the age of eight – and I think this is beautiful and I love it! –/ Decent-looking men masturbate in stairwells.” (Triumphal ode). Both poets, driven by a certain idea of ​​sanctity, had the same inability to break the siege of their skin with the overflow of someone else's dam, the same curse of sublimating the concrete ferocity of eros with the gentleness of the verses. Obviously, they are both “bigger than life”, but sometimes it makes me unnerved to watch, from my position as a hatter at the Procrastinators Club, the tantrums between them, just to see who occupies, in the internal organization, the position of President and Treasurer. Although Pessoa guessed more things, for example, what he wrote in the lesser-known Ode Martial and which is reflected in the situation we live in today, in a different way, with his heart in his hands: «MARTIAL ODE (…) Helahoho! helahoho! The poor widow's sewing machine who was bayoneted... She sewed indefinitely in the afternoon… The table where the old people played, Everything mixed, everything mixed with bodies, with blood, All one river, one wave, one dragging horror. Helahoho! helahoho! I unearthed the child's tin train pressed into the middle of the [road, And I cried like all the mothers in the world about the horror of life. My pantheistic feet tripped over the sewing machine [widow who was killed with a bayonet And that poor instrument of peace stuck a spear in my heart. Yes, I was the one to blame for everything, I was the soldier for them all Who killed, raped, burned and broke, It was me and my shame and my remorse like a shadow [misshapen They travel around the world like Ashavero, But behind my steps there are footsteps the size of infinity And a physical fear of being accountable to God makes me close my eyes. [eyes suddenly. (…) I ordered, captain, to shoot the trembling peasants, I let the daughters of all fathers tied to trees be raped, Now I saw that it was inside my heart that all this happened, And everything scalds and suffocates and I can't move without it [everything be the same. God have mercy on me, I didn't have it from anyone! LÀ-BAS, JE NE SAIS OÙ…” What is clear today, at this disastrous moment in which Cristiano & Companhia failed in their mission in Braga, and in which the self-sabotage of Russia's gas pipelines reminds us that Putin will be willing to do anything to maintain dominance over the areas endorsed, is that, bomb for bomb, the “bomb” of the Fifth Empire was preferable. However, even in this, my dears, we were irresolute, a little more on the side of piela than determined, and we procrastinated.

item.title: Japan | Member of nuclear regulator loses cell phone in China
item.description: Japanese authorities are investigating the loss of a professional cell phone, allegedly in China, which contained a confidential list of contacts from the Nuclear Regulation Authority, as confirmed to France-Presse by a person responsible for the organization. The incident, now made public, occurred at Shanghai airport, on November 3, when the employee was going through security control. The absence of the device was only noticed three days later, and, according to the Japanese press, it was not possible to block it or remotely erase its data as it was already out of reach. Although the cell phone did not contain direct access to nuclear data, according to the person in charge – who did not want to be identified – the list included names and contact details of members of the nuclear safety division of the regulatory authority – information that is not publicly accessible due to the sensitivity of the functions. The revelation comes in a context of growing tension between Beijing and Tokyo, after Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi suggested in November that the country could intervene militarily in the event of Chinese aggression against Taiwan. At the same time, the operator Tokyo Electric Power (TEPCO) is seeking final approval to reactivate the Kashiwazaki-Kariwa nuclear plant, the largest in the world, closed after the Fukushima disaster in 2011. Japan has been gradually resuming nuclear energy, with 14 reactors already reactivated, within the framework of carbon neutrality targets by 2050 and increased demand for electricity due to artificial intelligence. The lost cellphone was reported to Japanese data protection authorities in November, according to the nuclear regulator. The case reignites concerns about information security in the nuclear energy sector at a delicate moment in Japanese energy policy.

item.title: Hong Kong | Zhipu AI leads round of stock market debuts worth 1,030 ME
item.description: Investor interest in the technology market continues to bear fruit and leads more and more Chinese companies linked to Artificial Intelligence to enter the Hong Kong stock exchange The Chinese artificial intelligence company Zhipu AI debuted on the Hong Kong stock exchange yesterday, on a day when two other technology companies also entered the market, collectively raising 1.2 billion dollars. Zhipu, officially called Knowledge Atlas Technology and which adopts the name Z.ai in foreign markets, registered an upward trend in the middle of the session, with a value of 11.19 percent, after having raised around 559 million dollars. It is the first Chinese company specializing exclusively in large-scale language models to be listed on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. According to its co-founder and executive director, Zhang Peng, the choice of this financial center is related to the company's internationalization ambitions. Zhang said that Hong Kong and Southeast Asia will be the first markets to be explored, followed by the Middle East, Europe and the so-called “Global South”. The manager pointed to low costs as Zhipu's main attraction compared to competing models, with the aim of winning over new users. The technology company thus joins other Chinese companies in the sector that have taken advantage of investors' interest in the growth of AI in the country. One of Zhipu's main competitors, MiniMax – also a rival to OpenAI (creator of ChatGPT) and Anthropic (developer of Claude) – is scheduled to debut on the same exchange on Friday. Other premieres Yesterday, graphics chip maker Shanghai Iluvatar CoreX Semiconductor, which opened with gains of 31.5 percent after raising US$473 million, and surgical robot producer Edge Medical, which rose 36.4 percent, raising around US$154 million, also debuted in Hong Kong. Last week, Biren Technology, which specializes in AI chips, rose nearly 76 percent on its first day of trading. In December, two other companies in the sector, Moore Threads and MetaX, recorded increases of more than 100 percent on the Shanghai stock exchange. Despite admitting that Chinese models are closing the gap compared to North Americans, Zhang Peng acknowledged that gaps still persist in areas such as research, resources and innovation. Zhipu was placed on a commercial blacklist by the United States in 2025, making it difficult for it to access North American technology.

item.title: Cambodia liquidates bank of tycoon leader of fraud network
item.description: Cambodia announced yesterday the immediate liquidation of Prince Bank, owned by Chinese tycoon Chen Zhi, detained this week and extradited to China, where he is being investigated for leading a transnational fraud and human trafficking network. In a resolution published by the National Bank of Cambodia, the entity was prevented from accepting deposits and granting loans, one day after Phnom Penh confirmed Chen's arrest and handover to Beijing. The settlement will be supervised by the company Morisonkak MKA, which will guarantee the withdrawal of deposits by customers and the continuation of payment of ongoing credits. Prince Bank was one of more than 100 companies in the Prince Group conglomerate, founded by Chen Zhi, which over the past decade has expanded into areas such as tourism, technology, logistics, food and finance. Several of these companies have been identified by Washington as fronts for online fraud schemes and human trafficking networks in Southeast Asia. The Cambodian Interior Ministry said Chen, 37, was detained on Tuesday “as part of cooperation to combat transnational crime and at the request of Chinese authorities.” The operation also included the capture of Chinese citizens Xu Ji Liang and Shao Ji Hui, who were also extradited. Joint investigation Phnom Penh revealed that Chen was stripped of Cambodian nationality in December, by royal decree, months after ensuring that the businessman had obtained it legally. The arrest, according to the statement, was the result of “months of joint investigation” with China. Last October, the US Department of Justice charged Chen with financial crimes linked to forced labor. US authorities allege that the businessman led an “industrial-scale” online fraud operation, involving hundreds of victims held under duress in prison-like facilities in Cambodia. US courts confiscated $15 billion in bitcoin from the group, in the largest seizure of cryptocurrencies in its history. Last year, Cambodia's interior ministry spokesman stated that Chen was not in the country and that neither he nor his company faced local charges. The change in position has now been interpreted as a sign of greater alignment with Beijing in combating financial crime and cross-border fraud networks.

item.title: USA | Beijing condemns interception of ship linked to Russia
item.description: Beijing yesterday denounced the seizure by the United States of an oil tanker sailing under the Russian flag in international waters, classifying the action as “arbitrary” and a violation of international law. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning stated that the detention of ships from other countries on the high seas “seriously contravenes international law” and the principles of the United Nations Charter. The statements come after the US Coast Guard intercepted the tanker Marinera – formerly known as Bella 1 – in the North Atlantic, accusing it of violating the sanctions regime imposed by Washington. According to the United States, the ship was trying to access Venezuelan waters to load crude oil. Moscow has already described the operation as an “illegal interception” and demanded “humane and dignified” treatment for the crew. Beijing also reiterated its opposition to the unilateral sanctions imposed by Washington without the support of the United Nations, considering that they “lack a legal basis”. In response to news about a possible worsening of US sanctions against Russia – with warnings aimed at companies from countries such as China, India or Brazil – Mao Ning stressed that economic, commercial and energy cooperation between Beijing and Moscow is “normal” and “does not target third parties”, and therefore “should not be interfered with”. The seizure of the Marinera comes as part of growing US pressure on oil exports from Russia and Venezuela. Washington recently announced new measures to confiscate ships linked to the Venezuelan oil trade and indefinitely control the associated revenues. According to North American media outlets, the Marinera was part of the so-called “ghost fleet” used to circumvent Western sanctions, which has fueled diplomatic friction between Washington, Moscow and now also Beijing.

item.title: Greenland | China calls for respect for the UN Charter
item.description: Beijing defended yesterday that relations between countries must respect the principles of the United Nations Charter, following statements by the United States about possible military action to take control of Greenland. Chinese Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said at a press conference that Beijing's position has been consistent in defending that relations between States should be managed in accordance with the objectives and principles of the UN Charter, without commenting further on the case. The topic arose after Washington once again suggested the possibility of using military means in its strategy to acquire or influence control of Greenland, an issue that has generated opposition from European countries and the Danish government itself, which claim that the territory can only decide its future sovereignly. Mao's statements occur in a context of international tension amplified by the recent US military operation in Venezuela, in which US forces captured the Venezuelan leader, Nicolás Maduro, and which sparked debate about the legality of the use of force and respect for the sovereignty of States. China has intensified calls for respect for international law and state sovereignty following US external actions, stressing that any control of sovereign territory by another country must respect the norms and principles enshrined in the United Nations Charter.

item.title: Commerce | Beijing announces new measure against Japan
item.description: China yesterday worsened trade tensions with Japan by announcing an anti-dumping investigation into imports of a chemical gas used in the production of semiconductors, after imposing restrictions on the export of dual-use products. The Chinese Ministry of Commerce justified the measure based on a complaint from the domestic industry, which alleged a 31 percent drop in the prices of Japanese imports of dichloro silane between 2022 and 2024. “The ‘dumping’ of products imported from Japan has harmed the production and operations of our national industry,” the statement reads. The decision comes after Beijing banned on Tuesday the export to Japan of goods considered dual-use – with possible civil and military purposes. Relations between the two countries have deteriorated in recent weeks, after the new Japanese Prime Minister, Sanae Takaichi, suggested that the Japanese Armed Forces could intervene if China took action against Taiwan. Tensions rose further on Tuesday when Japanese lawmaker Hei Seki – previously sanctioned by Beijing for “spreading falsehoods” about Taiwan – visited the island and declared Taiwan an independent country. “I came to Taiwan to demonstrate this and tell the world that Taiwan is an independent country,” he said, according to Taiwan’s official news agency, CNA. Asked about these statements, the spokeswoman for the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Mao Ning, replied: “Hateful words from an insignificant villain do not deserve comment.” The director for Asia and Oceania Affairs at the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Masaaki Kanai, called on China to lift trade restrictions and classified as “unacceptable” any measure aimed exclusively at Japan and outside international practices. Tokyo, however, has not yet announced retaliation. Rare Trumps However, speculation is growing that China may impose restrictions on the export of rare earths to Japan, similar to what it already did with the United States in the context of the trade war between the two countries. China has most of the world's production of heavy rare earths, essential for the production of heat-resistant magnets used in the defense and electric vehicle industries. Although the ministry did not mention new restrictions in this sector, the official China Daily newspaper cited anonymous sources according to which Beijing is considering limiting exports of certain rare metals to Japan – information not independently confirmed. While relations with Japan worsen, China has sought to strengthen ties with South Korea. South Korean President Lee Jae Myung concluded yesterday a four-day visit to China – his first since taking office in June – during which he met with his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, and oversaw the signing of agreements in the areas of technology, trade, transport and environmental protection. During the visit, 24 export contracts were signed, worth a total of US$44 million, according to the South Korean Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The Chinese press also noted that, during the New Year holiday, South Korea overtook Japan as the main destination for international flights from mainland China. Beijing has advised against traveling to Japan, claiming that statements by Japanese authorities about Taiwan pose “significant risks” to the safety of Chinese citizens in the country.

item.title: Venezuela | Global Times warns of “serious erosion” of international order
item.description: An editorial in a Chinese Communist Party newspaper warned yesterday that the United States military operation, which resulted in the capture of the Venezuelan president, represents a serious erosion of the international order established after World War II. The Global Times denounces the “subversion of fundamental principles of international law”, including sovereign equality, non-interference in the internal affairs of States and the prohibition of the use of force, by allowing “certain countries to unilaterally decide who is guilty, who should be punished and in what way”. “If such practices are tolerated, international law will be reduced to a selectively applied tool, and the collective security mechanism established by the United Nations Charter will be emptied,” reads the editorial. The newspaper emphasizes that the detention and transfer of a serving head of state, without a clear warrant from the United Nations, is not only a violation of a country's sovereignty, but a direct attack on the predictability and authority of international law. “What is at stake is not just the security of Venezuela, but the future of the international legal order”, writes the English-language newspaper, recalling that several representatives expressed similar concerns at a meeting of the UN Security Council. The Global Times considers that the imposition of force over multilateral rules represents a return to the Hobbesian “state of nature”, where the strong dictate the rules. “The overwhelming majority of countries do not wish to return to an international jungle governed by the law of the strongest”, he states. Story factory The publication also criticizes what it classifies as “fabricated narratives” by Washington to justify the operation, stating that replacing legal norms with arbitrary political judgments only generates global instability and weakens the multilateral system. Beijing has openly spoken out against the capture of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said this week that the US “arbitrarily trampled on the sovereignty, security and legitimate rights and interests of Venezuela”, calling for the immediate release of Maduro and his wife. Against bullying The Chinese Government yesterday considered the alleged United States demand that Venezuela break off economic relations with Beijing as an act of intimidation as a condition for exploring and selling its oil. Questioned at a press conference about the information provided by the North American television channel ABC News, Mao Ning declared that Venezuela “is a sovereign country and enjoys full and permanent sovereignty over its natural resources and all economic activities in its territory”. According to ABC News, the Administration of US President Donald Trump demanded that Venezuelan interim president Delcy Rodríguez end ties with China, Russia, Iran and Cuba as a precondition for restarting the production and sale of crude oil. Mao described the alleged pressure as a “brazen use of force” and stated that the attempt to condition access to Venezuelan energy resources to a “United States first” logic constitutes a “typical case of intimidation” that “seriously violates international law, seriously infringes on Venezuela’s sovereignty” and “harms the rights of the Venezuelan people.” Mao reiterated that Beijing defends economic cooperation between sovereign states and highlighted that China “has always developed exchanges and cooperation with other countries based on mutual respect, equality and reciprocal benefit”.

item.title: Taiwan | Beijing accuses William Lai of “sabotaging peace”
item.description: China yesterday accused Taiwanese leader William Lai of “sabotaging peace” after his New Year's speech, in which he warned of increased pressure from Beijing and called for strengthening the island's defense. The reaction came from the Taiwan Affairs Office of the Chinese State Council, whose spokesman, Chen Binhua, classified the message as “full of lies, hostility and malice” and accused Lai of repeating “separatist fallacies” about Taiwan’s independence and “inciting confrontation between the two sides of the strait”. According to Beijing, Lai resorted to the rhetoric of “democracy versus authoritarianism” to “confuse fellow Taiwanese and deceive international public opinion”, demonstrating an “incorrigible” stance in support of the island’s independence. Chen Binhua went further to describe Lai as a “destabilizer of peace”, “creator of crises” and “instigator of war”, arguing that the Taiwanese leader has “deliberately intensified tensions” since taking office and promotes a strategy of “preparing for war with the aim of achieving independence”. “The failure of Taiwan’s independence is inevitable”, reads the statement, which reiterates that “Taiwan is part of China” and calls on the island’s population to “firmly oppose separatism and external interference”.

item.title: Hong Kong | Secretary cancels visit to the USA
item.description: Hong Kong's Secretary for Innovation, Technology and Industry, Sun Dong, canceled, without any explanation, a visit to the United States, four hours after the trip was announced. In a statement released at 12:00 on Tuesday, the government of the Chinese region said that Sun would participate in the Consumer Electronics Show (CES), one of the largest technology and consumer electronics fairs in the world, which is taking place in Las Vegas. The secretary would lead the largest delegation ever from Hong Kong to the CES, made up of 61 companies, the statement highlighted. The trip would include a visit to the city of San Francisco, where Sun would visit and “also exchange experiences with local technology companies and a university in the Silicon Valley region”. However, in another statement, published at 4:20 pm, with just one sentence, the Government announced that Sun had canceled his visit to the United States. The secretary's office told Hong Kong media that the Government is constantly carrying out “dynamic assessments” on the desirability of international travel. “After an assessment, it was decided to cancel the trip,” said a spokesperson for the office. The Government highlighted that the business delegation will participate in the Las Vegas fair, led by directors from the Hong Kong Trade Promotion Council. The cancellation of Sun Dong's visit came on the same day that China accused the United States of placing its domestic legislation above international law, in reaction to the detention of the President of Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro, during a US military operation.

item.title: Sofia Ferreira da Silva, author of a study on opera in the Mao years: “Silk Road was the biggest influence”
item.description: In “Singing the Revolution: The Role of Songs and Opera in the Spread of Communism in Mao Zedong's China”, Sofia Ferreira da Silva analyzes the way in which songs and opera spread political ideals, leaving marks on the country's cultural panorama. The analysis came from the doctoral thesis in Artistic Studies, defended by the author at Universidade Nova de Lisboa What was the musical environment like in the country before Mao Zedong came to power? China was, and continues to be, a territory with a huge variety of practices at regional, local and ethnic levels. We can speak of four main types: music of a more erudite nature, symbolized by court music (yayue) and guqin music, more centered on Confucian ideals and with ritual functions and self-cultivation of individual morals; folk music, with vocal and instrumental genres varying according to region and ethnicity; Taoist, Buddhist and other religious music; and traditional opera, such as Kunqu and Peking, Sichuan and Canton operas, combining singing, declamation, stylized movements and martial arts. The biggest influence on Chinese music was, perhaps, the Silk Road, as a good part of the musical instruments that are now considered “Chinese”, such as the erhu, the pipa, the suona and the sanxian, have their origins in foreign instruments brought to Chinese territory, and which were gradually adapted and incorporated into their music. On the other hand, some narrative and operatic genres evolved from the adaptation and combination of counterparts from the territories crossed by this route. If it weren't for the Silk Road, traditional Chinese music would be radically different. What other influences are there? The other big influence is Western music. This, despite having entered the country in the 16th and 17th centuries, was felt with greater intensity from the middle of the 19th century and throughout the 20th century. The growing foreign presence and influence led to the systematic introduction of Western notation, academic training along European lines and Western classical and popular music genres, which would be assimilated in varying ways by Chinese composers, such as Ma Sicong, Li Jinhui or Xian Xinghai, combining them or not with traditional music motifs. In the thesis, he talks about two major changes in the Mao years, with the creation of the so-called “model shows (yangbanxi)” and the revolutionary Peking operas. How did these formats help to reshape the music scene at the time? The model shows, which include Peking operas and revolutionary songs, played an important role in reforming the Maoist musical landscape, implying changes not only in musical styles, but also in the social function of music. Production became entirely subordinated to the political project of the Chinese Communist Party (PCC), resulting in the mandatory membership of artists and designated artistic associations, and the suppression, through criticism in the media, of musical elements or genres considered “feudal”, “bourgeois” or “superstitious”. In opposition, and following successive political movements and campaigns, other formats were promoted, more in line with the regime's ideals. How, in concrete terms? In the case of the “yangbanxi”, from the Cultural Revolution, the fact that they were called “model” implied that all new creations must strictly follow the aesthetic precepts established through them, especially the rules of the “basic task”, with the construction of revolutionary heroic figures as the ultimate aim of artistic creation. There were also the “Three Prominences”, with the attribution of greater or lesser prominence to a certain character depending on their degree of positivity or negativity, their function in the plot. These rules guided not only the narrative structure and the role of the characters, but also aspects such as the integration between music and gestures, the construction of costumes and sets, and the harmony between traditional and Western musical elements. This codification would aim, to this extent, to guarantee the ideological and aesthetic uniformity essential to the creation of a controlled, functional and politically effective musical culture within the framework of the objectives of the revolution. What are the main political messages conveyed through these two types of shows? The first big idea is the almost religious loyalty to Mao Zedong and the unconditional observance of his ideas. It is his thought that inspires and guides the actions of the heroes and heroic characters, the second most important category of characters in revolutionary operas, and leads them to the successful completion of the mission assigned to them or to heroic sacrifice in favor of the communist cause. The second is the class struggle as the driving force of history. We have, on the one hand, the oppressive, capitalist, imperialist and feudal class as the villain, and on the other the working people, exploited and oppressed by the former, suffering the greatest storms at their hands. The conflicts and difficult situations faced by the heroes or other positive characters, such as the death of family members, imprisonment or slavery, were always the direct expression of this struggle, and their resolution would only come from the revolutionary stance and the assumption of an active role in the construction of socialism. And the third idea present in the shows? This is collectivism, as a true revolutionary places the interests of the Party and the People above any individual dream or desire. No matter how prominent his role, the hero needs popular support to complete his mission: his aspirations are the aspirations of the people, and it is in solidarity between all that difficulties are overcome and the much-desired socialist harmony is achieved. Personal achievement only has value if it serves the collective cause, and individual sacrifice is glorified when it contributes to common progress. Operas promote, to this extent, a worldview where individual identity dissolves into the identity of the revolutionary collective, and where the active participation of the masses is not only desirable, but necessary. These were years of so-called cultural Maoism, as mentioned in the thesis. How is it characterized? Cultural Maoism presents points of contact regarding the subordination of art to politics, the valorization of the daily lives of the masses as the raw material for creation and the defense of its widespread popularization. However, it is distinguished by its emphasis on the proletarianization of the artist himself, who should abandon his position as a distant intellectual and become an active member of the working people, learning through practice and inserting himself in their daily struggles. What are the main influences of this movement? In addition to the Marxist-Leninist matrix, cultural Maoism would be marked by Confucian influences, giving art an ethical and formative function, as in Confucius, Mencius or Xunzi, art shaped character. However, in the Maoist context, this molding was channeled towards the construction of socialist consciousness and the eradication of traces of the bourgeois mentality. One of the central principles of this policy was the “mass line”, a kind of circular cultural dynamic in which popular ideas and expressions were collected and systematized by the Party, before being returned to the people in a clearer and more politically oriented way. Another aspect to consider is the appreciation of native and foreign cultural heritage, condensed in the maxim “use the past to serve the present, use the foreign to serve China”. In what way? To create new artistic works, Mao recommended the initial study of Western works, considered “scientific” and technically superior, before selectively incorporating elements of Chinese tradition. In both cases, the value of artistic forms lay in their social and political function, not in their preservation as heritage. In this context, the PCC leader proposed two criteria for artistic evaluation: the political, which required the promotion of national unity and the rejection of ideas contrary to the Party; and the artistic, which presupposed technical and aesthetic rigor following an abstract notion of “scientific criteria of art” at the service of the masses. This double requirement replaced, in Maoism, the Confucian distinction between moral quality and aesthetic quality. In these years, what were the biggest influences on songwriting? The composition of songs was greatly influenced by two great musical traditions: the native, with the use of regional melodies and motifs and those of the various ethnic minorities that make up the territory; and the Western, in which I include the Soviet musical tradition, most visible in marches and so-called “art songs”, which could be understood as a type of revolutionary ‘lieder’ or with highly politicized content. The influence of each of them was more or less visible depending on the political situation of the territory. How did the years of “cultural Maoism” change the country’s musical landscape? Some aspects of the production of Cultural Revolution operas, such as the introduction of the Western orchestra and the use of techniques from Western music, the incorporation of more realistic scenarios and the melodramatic nature of the stories influenced and continue to influence the production of new Beijing operas, especially those with contemporary or historical themes relating to the 20th century. XX. Over the last 30 years, operas with historical themes have also been produced with some of these elements, especially in terms of music and settings, such as “Cao Cao and Yang Xiu”. Some remnants of this period can also be seen in the interpretation of traditional operas, especially in the presentation of arias or excerpts on television programs. I see countless performances that combine, just like in the revolutionary repertoire, arrangements with a Western orchestra and realistic scenarios, with extensive use of new technologies. However, what I consider to be the greatest remnant of revolutionary operas will, perhaps, be a greater artistic audacity on the part of the creators of new operas. It is an issue that deserves further study by the academy, but, from my observations as a spectator, I notice a greater openness to the incorporation of elements from other arts, such as dance and theater, and a greater complexity in the characters, especially those considered negative, less antagonistic, with more nuances when it comes to motivations for acting in a certain way. It is obvious that the psychological suffering inflicted by these operas on an entire generation of Chinese people is undeniable and cannot, under any circumstances, be forgotten; however, model operas boosted the creative impetus of composers and librettists, in line with the evolutionary process, of fusion with other arts, of Peking Opera over the centuries.

item.title: Alfredo Gomes Dias, historian, on Rocha Vieira: “A historical figure, whether he wanted to or not”
item.description: Launched on Thursday in Porto, with the seal of War and Peace, “Macau: The Last Transition – Vasco Rocha Vieira (1991–1999)” is the result of 20 years of work by historian Alfredo Gomes Dias. The work contains personal testimonies from Rocha Vieira and documented details of the last Portuguese Administration of Macau Another book has just been released about Rocha Vieira and the last Portuguese administration of Macau. Tell me about the beginning of this project. This project is more or less 20 years old, and began when I met Rocha Vieira, in 2005, to write a text for the book “Governadores de Macau” [published by Livros do Oriente in 2013]. In the midst of this, I discovered that there was a personal document fund of General Rocha Vieira, while governor. As a historian, I was excited by the idea. I offered to do a project with him, which we called a “report”. All the documents were at his home, in Lagoa, where he was from. They were then deposited in a space provided by Mafra City Council and between 2007 and 2013 I worked on this documentation. It was lonely and long work, because I had to organize 1,700 boxes of documentation and combine it with my work as a teacher. Rocha Vieira kept postponing the project, saying no, but in 2016 he told me to move forward with the “report”, the book. I finished the first version in 2021. It is a committed book, in the sense that it aims to give General Rocha Vieira's vision of what his Government was like. This is not an academic work. He had complete access to the personal file. He gave me the green light to consult all the documentation, I had no restrictions. Rocha Vieira told me one story or another in detail, gave me guidelines and revealed to me his concerns during his government. He told me some positions he had and then the different paths they took, and the entire book is built around the many conversations I had with the general, in which I also use documentation. We have a vision of everything that happened between 1991 and 1999 and the governor's actions in the different dimensions of the Administration, at an economic, social and political level, in relations with China and Lisbon, with Hong Kong, and then everything related to the work related to the transformation of the territory, such as the birth of Cotai and the major works that were carried out. There is also talk about the transition phase and the major themes, such as the entry of Chinese troops into Macau, the ceremony and how it was organized. Today we live in an immediate world, and at today's speed it's always strange to say that this book took 20 years to make. Can we say that this is the first time that we have such a complete testimony of Rocha Vieira's vision of his Government? The edited biography [Vasco Rocha Vieira – Todos os Portos a que Aguei] already gives many ideas about his concerns. What I ended up doing was not focusing so much on the general's entire life, but only on the years of the Government and developing as much as possible many of the issues that Pedro Vieira raised in this biography. What subjects are then further developed in this new work? I describe very well all the processes linked to Macau's transition, such as the issue of laws and localization, the need to translate them into Chinese. This was a gigantic job. Then I discuss the construction of major works, the birth of Cotai. All of this based on the original plans and plans designed for Cotai, where the beginning of the idea for this area is known. Any historian who, in the future, wants to study the transition process must necessarily go through this book. I don't want to say that what's there is definitive, because it never is. But it is important to have this basis and testimony, which is enriched and substantiated by documentation. I imagine that the controversies of the Rocha Vieira Government are also in the book. The quarrel with Jorge Sampaio, the creation of the Fundação Oriente in Portugal. What is Rocha Vieira’s testimony about these two moments? He always maintained the same speech compared to what he had already said publicly. There is a specific chapter on Fundação Oriente, where, with the support of documentation, an attempt is made to explain the process and why Rocha Vieira, when he arrived in Macau, felt the need to solve a problem that had been dragging on and which was important to overcome. It describes how he managed to resolve it, as it was an issue that was making dialogue with the Chinese authorities difficult. It explains how Rocha Vieira interacted with the different Governments of the [Portuguese] Republic and the different Presidents, the positions he took in order to guarantee what was his responsibility. While he was at the head of the Government, Rocha Vieira always tried to assert his views, and one of the interesting things is that I had access to copies of minutes of meetings of the State Council, in which Rocha Vieira presented his vision on the situation in Macau. It's an interesting contribution. But he explains that the way he spoke with President Mário Soares was completely different from the way he spoke with Jorge Sampaio. The institutional relationship changed, the way of attending a meeting was also different. This is explained, but without going into the personal side of the dispute. Did Rocha Vieira leave Macau with a feeling of accomplishment? I think he left Macau very convinced, and the entire transfer ceremony ends up giving us this image that Portugal left in the best possible way. We also have to think that we are talking about two completely different countries, and that one of them is giant. And that, despite this difference, it was possible to maintain an almost equal dialogue between two States to resolve, in the best way, a specific issue that was Macau. What surprised me most about Rocha Vieira's vision was that he changed the centrality of his vision to Macau. In what sense? In general, the Portuguese and the authorities spoke of Macau thinking about guaranteeing the transition process without jeopardizing Portugal's interests. And General Rocha Vieira reverses the terms of the issue, that is, to guarantee Macau's interests, with the idea that guaranteeing Macau's interests would be the same as guaranteeing Portugal's interests. It looks like the same thing, but it's not. This vision, for me, was surprising. Why? Because it went against what was the most common discourse among the authorities and people responsible for the Portuguese administration [of Macau]. This central idea ends up changing the way he organizes his Government, how he acts and the type of actions he triggers. They all had to do with this deep conviction, that, in the remaining years, a great development of Macau would be guaranteed, the affirmation of Portuguese culture, supporting institutions, or even with the Portuguese School of Macau (EPM), whose solution ended up not being the one he proposed. It turned out to be a minimalist option. What, specifically, was Rocha Vieira’s position? It was to ensure that the old Macau High School was the EPM, which would give the school a completely different dimension compared to [the current location]. It has nothing to do with it. He didn't just want a Portuguese school, but also a space where it was possible to develop cultural activities, create a cultural hub in Macau linked to Portugal, and with a much more dignified option than what was, later, the option of the Ministry of Education, in the figure of Marçal Grilo, who chose [the location] of the old Commercial School. Therefore, the focus has always been to guarantee and develop Macau's interests, its autonomy, and the airport issue was fundamental to guarantee Macau's autonomy. It was also intended that Macau would adhere to international agreements regarding respect for human rights. The idea was that, by managing to guarantee Macau's interests, thinking of the territory as part of China's second system, and that if we invested a lot in Macau, we would, naturally, be defending Portuguese interests and leaving a great legacy. What was the most complex dossier for Rocha Vieira? I think he had great regrets regarding the Ministry of Education's option for Portuguese schools. From the conversations I had with him [that's what it seemed to me]. Then there were the security issues, with the sects, which ended up being resolved. The years 1997 and 1998 were very critical moments in Macau, but as it always had good relations with the Chinese authorities, this led to China realizing the situation, starting to collaborate more with the Portuguese authorities in Macau, in order to control the problem. About Cotai, how did the idea come about? It arises in the context of the airport works, when it is realized that it would be relatively easy to mobilize the land that was associated with the airport works, taking advantage of that moment to make a connection and create, essentially, a second urban center in Macau. Cotai's initial plans had to do with urban space, green and industrial spaces. The entire plan was designed to bring together different areas, social spaces, such as schools or health, as if Cotai were a mini-city, so to speak, in the territory. But who actually had the idea? It was an idea from Rocha Vieira's Executive, developed with secretaries. The idea came from him, when he was faced with the issue of the works, and was then developed with the team. He was always concerned about developing things with the team, also ensuring continuity with what had been done before. When he talked to me, he was careful to say: “this didn't start with me”, or that this or that secretary had been fundamental for a certain job. He never wanted to take credit that wasn't his, and this is also a great recognition from previous governors. Therefore, Cotai was not supposed to have so much area dedicated to the game. From what I analyzed in the documents, there was no idea of ​​giving up such a large space for entertainment, with casinos. I think the initial vision for Cotai was a little more balanced, with housing, schools, health centers, green spaces. It was supposed to be a new urban space that would be created with all the services necessary to function, it wasn't just supposed to be games. The moments in which Rocha Vieira clutches the flag to his chest, moved, will go down in history. Did he remember those moments with him? Yes, but despite the historical dimension of his role, Rocha Vieira was not exactly aware of the historical role he was playing. He was there with a clear mission and objectives, without really thinking about the role he could have in the future. Once, when we were having lunch, I told him that we could put our work into perspective, but that he was going to become a historical figure in the history of Portugal, whether he wanted to or not. And the funny thing is that he looked at me with a face like he had never thought of that, with a very surprised look. In fact, it is unthinkable to take away his status as the last Portuguese governor in Macau in hundreds of years of history. On top of that, he was there for a long period [9 years], when most governors were there for three or four years.

item.title: Christian Montag, UM Institute for Collaborative Innovation: “AI cannot imitate the human touch”
item.description: Can artificial intelligence help combat loneliness? The issue was analyzed in a study by the University of Macau, led by academic Christian Montag. The director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation emphasizes that AI tools “are not long-term solutions” on a psychological level How can artificial intelligence (AI) help overcome feelings of loneliness, if social networks cannot achieve this goal? The “needs and gratifications theory” states that technology can only be successful if its use satisfies human needs, such as, for example, the need for social interaction. With AI companions, whether as stand-alone products or integrated into social media platforms, we have reached a new level, because human beings start talking to an artificial person and not with another human person, as happens on social media. Specific problems arise with these new AI companions, in that there are overly pleasant and charming AI systems that do not challenge a person's biased views of the world. Furthermore, many people around the world have become overly dependent on these products, using them without critical reflection. One of the conclusions of your study is that AI cannot, on its own, resolve feelings of loneliness. What steps in the investigation were followed to reach this conclusion? There are well-conducted studies that show that interactions with AI companions can actually reduce feelings of loneliness. We do not doubt these results nor deny the potential that can arise from these interactions between humans and AI, as long as such systems are designed safely and when a human is not available. That said, we believe that these interactions between humans and AI do not represent a long-term solution. Why? This is due to the absence of social contact and the real presence of another human being when turning to AI companions based on large-scale language models, especially in moments of desperation. We have reviewed a vast literature that demonstrates that we need to take our evolutionary heritage seriously, with the real need for other human beings, particularly in the age of AI. Our perspective is based on many years of research in the area of ​​affective neuroscience. Still, it is clearly necessary to develop more new empirical studies that directly address interactions with AI and support this vision. We run the risk of AI causing profound cognitive changes in people. To what extent? Can we change as human beings, especially when it comes to our need for others? The same discussion arose with the appearance of smartphones. It is important to note that this oldest discussion has not yet been resolved: what happens or happened to our cognitive abilities when we began to permanently outsource the learning of telephone numbers, the guidance from A to B, among other tasks, to a machine? Recent research from MIT [Massachusetts Institute of Technology] suggests that the brain is less activated when using ChatGPT for writing tasks, compared to writing without such support. To me, this is not surprising and should not lead to moral panics. We have other more urgent problems, such as when real difficulties arise when inequalities in society increase, this is because some people use AI and others do not invest in this area. What are the concrete impacts? Some people may soon become very, very productive, while those who are not educated to use AI properly will not be able to keep up. Interestingly, we have observed in recent research that people with a deep learning style are more willing to engage with AI to become more productive. As for the question of whether we have changed in relation to our need for others, I highly doubt that, as these evolutionary impulses are genetically anchored in our species and we cannot simply eliminate them. Social needs are an essential part of what it means to be human. Could these cognitive changes, if they occur, be more significant in young people than in adults, for example? Interesting question. We know, from some studies on attitudes towards AI, that younger users tend to have more positive views about AI and, therefore, are more likely to adopt it in their daily lives. However, we are currently observing something quite problematic, such as the fact that AI is often eliminating jobs for young people just leaving university. Thus, AI appears to make it more difficult to enter the job market after obtaining a university degree. In other words, a lack of work experience makes things difficult for many young people. In the end, this could also lead to young people's perception of AI becoming more negative soon. How should governments legislate or adopt policies to promote healthy acceptance and use of AI in society and schools? We see very different approaches around the world to respond to the AI ​​revolution. I am German and, in Europe, we are seeing strong regulatory efforts with the so-called Artificial Intelligence Regulation (Artificial Intelligence Act). Personally, I am not convinced that the current European regulatory scheme is well planned, as I think it is too strict and, in some points, uses legally undefined terms, although I applaud the aim of promoting reliable AI and trying to reduce harm. I think the current regulation of AI in the European Union could go too far and end up harming the European economy by stifling much-needed innovation. But there are real dangers associated with AI and some regulation is needed. What dangers? I'm talking, for example, about the unregulated fusion between biotechnology and AI that could result in harm if people start to “create” new viruses in their backyards. I find Singapore's approach based on lifelong learning as a response to the AI ​​revolution very interesting. The Singapore Government offers its citizens the possibility of obtaining an academic degree in AI from the age of 40, with financial support from the State itself. What I like about this approach is that we need to remind people that it is also their responsibility to acquire new skills throughout their lives. This mentality must be instilled from an early age in schools. In what areas of our lives can large-scale language models (LLMs) do more good than harm? There are many routine and repetitive tasks where AI will be really useful to humans. However, we know from scientific literature that humans experience what is called “algorithm aversion”: in some areas of our lives, people do not like AI playing a role. For example, when we talk about couples therapy, people clearly prefer to talk to a human being than an AI system. Perhaps the closer we come to our evolutionary heritage in terms of caring for each other, the more the role of AI must be carefully monitored and reflected upon if we want it to have a place there. Personally, I wouldn't want to see my child being taken care of in kindergarten by an AI-powered robot. How should psychology adapt to AI, given the growing number of people using it for this purpose? There are different perspectives on this topic. Firstly, not everyone knows that psychology is a discipline that relies heavily on data. Therefore, psychology students are trained to become excellent data scientists. In this context, it is logical that our discipline adopts AI as a data analysis tool. However, I think it speaks to how psychologists view the increasing use of AI in human relationships. As with many things, this is complex. If AI enables better human communication, such as improving hearing aids for people with hearing problems, that is very welcome. If AI replaces human relationships, from my perspective it will cause problems. As we exposed in our most recent work, AI cannot currently successfully imitate human social touch or the real presence of another person. At the Center for Cognitive and Brain Science at the University of Macau, what are the main projects developed in this area? We have unique research opportunities at the University of Macau to study interactions between humans and AI, using neuroscientific techniques. I hope we can publish very interesting discoveries in the near future. Humanity still lives here Recently published in the scientific journal “Trends and Cognitive Sciences”, the article “Can AI really help solve the loneliness epidemic?” [Can AI Really Help Solve the Loneliness Epidemic?] counts Christian Montag, associate director of the Institute for Collaborative Innovation at the University of Macau (UM) as lead author, followed by academics Michiel Spapé, associate professor at the Center for Cognitive and Brain Sciences at UM, and Benjamin Becker, professor at the Department of Psychology at the University of Hong Kong, as co-authors. According to a press release released by UM regarding this investigation, one of the main conclusions is that AI “will probably not be a long-term solution to human loneliness”. Quoted in this note, Christian Montag stated that “if a person is lonely, they long for the physical presence of someone close to them”, and this “is very difficult to imitate with the available chatbots”. "The major language models operate primarily through text communication. Clearly, this is not enough to provide lonely people with the best cure for loneliness: direct in-person support," he stated. According to the World Health Organization, “loneliness affects one in six people worldwide”, having been “identified as a global public health concern”. Despite the sign, the study points to a positive side of this universe, noting that “AI technology has significant potential to support human beings in moments of psychological crisis, especially when human intervention is not available”. However, “the researchers argue that the technology must be made safer before it can be used in this context”, emphasizing “the importance of remembering our evolutionary heritage and the need for genuine interpersonal connections”.

item.title: Luís Bernardino, academic: “We need to define a defense cooperation strategy” for the CPLP
item.description: The book “25 Years of Defense Cooperation at CPLP” was released in 2023 in digital format and, two years later, reached the printed version. Luís Bernardino, co-author linked to the Universidade Autónoma de Lisboa, highlights positive developments since the creation of the Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries, despite inaction and controversies with Equatorial Guinea “25 Years of Defense Cooperation in the CPLP [Community of Portuguese Speaking Countries]” was released as an e-book and is now available in print. Why edit this book? This book talks about the 25 years of cooperation in the CPLP defense area and is written by me, together with a colleague from Brazil, Camila Rizzi. It results from a research project developed at the CPLP Strategic Analysis Center, based in Mozambique. It has the CPLP defense component and makes strategic reflection on this topic. Due to the fact that 25 years of cooperation have passed in this area, we wanted to carry out an evaluation and the book so that it would remain in the history of the organization. In 2023, there were no financial conditions to publish the book on paper as we wanted, and it was now launched on November 18th, in Maputo. There is criticism regarding the effective action of the CPLP. Do you consider that this organism has grown sustainably? The assessment I make is in the area of ​​defense. When the CPLP was created, cooperation in the area of ​​defense was not included in the initial six areas. This area only emerged in 1998. The CPLP was born with six main areas – culture, language, political-diplomatic concentration – and currently has 26 areas of cooperation, which is proof that it has grown in a sustained manner. Obviously, with ups and downs, situations have become easier over these almost 30 years. But what stands out in this book, in the area of ​​defense, is that there was a very consolidated and participated growth. In these 25 years, a lot of interesting things have been done and the evaluation is positive. And the future? We need to define a defense cooperation strategy and what we want for the CPLP in this area over the next 25 years. This is the challenge we face, of greater activity and initiative, so that cooperation and defense can be strategic in what is cooperation within States. So that it can be more visible and effectively allow for growth, participation and development, or even greater commitment, in regional contexts. But looking at the past, present and future, what has the dynamic been like in the defense area? The book shows a certain dynamic of substantial constitutional growth in the first phase. Then there were very interesting developments, with some protocols and cooperation at the level of the Armed Forces, but there is still a lot to do, namely looking at the area of ​​defense cooperation as a strategic area. The global geopolitical system appears to be changing very quickly, following a multipolar path. Should the CPLP have another role in this context, with actors such as China, Russia or the United States? The CPLP is not a multilateral instrument, it is not an organization of that level. We have to place the CPLP at the level of the Commonwealth, for example, of organizations at a cultural, linguistic level, of partnership between countries, of concern for development. What I usually say is that the CPLP is a good diplomatic communication instrument, a soft power in areas related to conflict management and prevention. Let us not expect there to be armed forces, or an army, from the CPLP. This body is one of dialogue and cooperation. What we do, in terms of defense, is exactly that, create partnerships so that there are mechanisms for responding to disasters, to provide training capacity for the armed forces. There are even those who ask the question: why did the CPLP not intervene in Cabo Delgado, in Mozambique, on the issue of terrorism? And why? Because the CPLP is not a hard power mechanism, it has no capacity, doctrine, logistics, mandate or viability to be used in combat operations. And CPLP Member States are very aware that we are a very good mechanism for cooperation, partnership and development, with contributions to culture and language. Therefore, the CPLP will not intervene in the conflict between Russia and Ukraine, because that is not its area, nor does it have mechanisms for this dynamic. Is the existence of the CPLP justified? I think so, obviously, because, as I said, the CPLP is a very good instrument in terms of cooperation, the dissemination of the Portuguese language, of history. The fact is that we have around 350 million people who speak Portuguese. We have 30 countries that are associated observers, such as Ukraine, Chile, and Portuguese culture is represented in this organization. Each country has what it wants from the CPLP and gives it the importance it thinks it should give, and this depends on the foreign policy of each State. But I think the CPLP makes a lot of sense in the world we live in, and does so as a multilateral representative of language, culture, cooperation between Portuguese-speaking states, and those that ultimately have some affinity [with the Portuguese-speaking world]. The Macau issue is very specific to this organization. Macau has the role of a commercial platform between China and Portuguese-speaking countries, and China has an agenda for Lusophony. Before 1999 Macau had its own status within the CPLP, as it was administered by Portuguese. There was a Joint Declaration that allowed Macau, not being a Member State, to have, in a certain way, a protocol [with the CPLP]. When it became a Macao SAR, things changed and it lost that connection status, and Macau is not a member of the CPLP, and obviously cannot be. Neither does China, and it cannot be. Therefore, there is an associated observer status here that arises for countries, international and regional organizations, and even territorial entities with their own administration, which is also not quite the case in Macau. The territory is in limbo, between having a very strong history linked to Lusofonia, and having an administration very linked to China, which gives it, in my perspective, two dynamics. In what sense? Macau is a fundamental element in the connection between the CPLP countries and China. For all reasons, but due to the issue of language, history, and its representation, it is a fundamental actor in this cooperation. Macau must effectively be seen as a partner and as a gateway for China to Portuguese-speaking countries. This is what, in a way, is already happening, and this is what the CPLP will be paying attention to, in this relationship in which Macau has a special status. Whether we like it or not, it has an impact. Macau is an attractive factor in facilitating relations between China and Angola, Portugal or Brazil. Does Equatorial Guinea's stay in the CPLP raise questions of credibility? I agree with you. In these 30 years, it has been one of the main difficult moments in creating consensus. I remember that Equatorial Guinea was admitted in 2014, but there was already a process in the previous analysis phase. There was always an extension, year after year, and it was difficult to reach a consensus within the CPLP countries. In 2014, there was a summit in Timor-Leste and, through the action of Brazil and Angola, there was, in a way, a lot of pressure for Equatorial Guinea to join. But there are two principles, for better and for worse, that justify Equatorial Guinea's presence in the CPLP. What are… The first argument is that, in fact, Equatorial Guinea has Portuguese as its official language in its Constitution, despite us knowing that the Portuguese language, for example, covers four or five percent of society as a whole, and I am already being quite generous. But there is a commitment from the Equatorial Guinea authorities to develop Portuguese as a working language and there is a historical connection to Portuguese culture and Lusophony. Another criterion is the promise that, in the next constitutional review, a commitment will be made to abolish the death penalty. As for Portuguese, it's something that takes generations, it's not done from one year to the next. Not even in the next 10 or 15 years will we have Portuguese perfectly implemented. There is some shyness, a commitment, in a way. As for the death penalty, the fact is that, it seems, some change has been achieved. There has never been a death penalty action again [since accession]. And there is hope that, in the next constitutional review, this fact will be abolished from the Constitution and that it may, effectively, cease to exist. As a member of the CPLP, these changes will be easier and more visible and, in the future, Equatorial Guinea can effectively assume CPLP status taking these premises into account. I don't know if it will happen, I leave here a reluctance, and this is a challenging moment for the CPLP itself. Work needs to be done from within, so that Equatorial Guinea can be at the same level as other countries, especially in these two areas. What is certain is that there remains a certain lack of transparency regarding what is happening in the country. We are aware that Equatorial Guinea has major problems with issues of democratic legitimacy and elections. There are a series of situations that we recognize are not perfectly adequate given the status of CPLP countries. I think there is hope that things can change, an attempt to create space for Portuguese to grow within Equatorial Guinea, and also a commitment to greater openness and participation. What is a fact is that Equatorial Guinea has participated in CPLP meetings, and I have participated in some. In international situations we have to be pragmatic, and we hope that, just because Equatorial Guinea is in the CPLP, this can help Guinea itself to develop some mechanical gestures.

item.title: Piménio Ferreira: “Anti-gypsy rhetoric has always worked in Portugal”
item.description: Piménio Ferreira, better known as Gitelles Ferreira, anti-racist activist, 34 years old, physical engineer, Romani national. He is a man with a provocative speech, a corrosive, gentle humor and a smile that leaves no one indifferent. Gitelles, we live in an intercultural land and gypsies – in particular – have lived in Portugal for around five centuries. What happens so that gypsy communities continue to be “on the margins” of so-called society? We need to change the model of society. This is extremely stratified, placing people in subordinate positions to privilege a violent minority. The white social structure is patriarchal and racist. What is called the ‘margin’ of society is in fact an intrinsic place within it, which belongs to it. In other words, gypsy people have been included in this model of society since they discovered Europe and its kingdoms. The problem is the model of society that is maintained and the place to which they were relegated and how they were relegated: with violence, in a status of inferiority compared to white people, without the right to human dignity, to found a family, to choose their own language and religion, expropriated of any and all cultural and material rights. A place built and maintained to this day by genocidal and ethnocidal violence and persecution. In 1463, Vasco Gitano was granted an estate. In 1521, the gitanos, or gypsies, were already used as a reference for everything that is considered bad in the model of society. The “counter-example” compared to white that would stand out in a positive way. The ‘angel’ and the ‘demon’; the ‘other’, the enemy; the one against whom any attack and persecution is legitimate. Including the prohibition of defending oneself, having weapons, any type of property, and the right to stay. And is it because they are denied the right to stay that we still have nomadic gypsy communities within the country today? Yes, without a doubt. There are many ways to force nomadism: directly, by prohibiting permanence and expelling with police or military force; indirectly, refusing public or private housing to Roma people, because they are Roma; and also through the gentrification process. I read the results of a survey by the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights, where it is said that approximately 80% of Roma respondents live below the risk of poverty threshold in their country; one in three gypsies lives in a house without running water; one in three Roma belongs to a family in which someone went to bed hungry at least once in the previous month; and 50% of Roma aged between 6 and 24 do not attend school. Why does this happen like this? It is the historic persecution that continues. There is no impoverishment that does not have an external cause. In this case, a political system of total expropriation is imposed on the basis of violence. As early as 1648, D João IV, the Restorer, prohibited ‘giving or renting houses to gypsies’. The same D João IV who achieved the kingdom of Portugal thanks to D. Jerónimo da Costa and his 250 Knights. The same D. Jerónimo da Costa who died defending Portugal's independence from Castile. Gypsy, like his wife and children. Among prohibitions on permanence, “that gypsies do not enter the kingdom and those who are in it leave” (D João III, 1526), ​​with expulsions, banishment to the galleys, expropriation of goods and properties, imposed with penalties of flogging, mutilation and death, systematically carried out to this day (even in 2011 the Municipal Council of Faro wanted to ban gypsies in the municipality). The prohibition of working for others (no one employs gypsy workers, and those who do do so in complete precariousness, for poorly paid positions and without rights and dignified conditions). They are unable to remain dependent on self-employment, they are unable to invest, due to extreme expropriation. They become dependent on precariousness. If you want to know what it's like to live in pure neoliberalism, get to know the lives of gypsies. The reality of these is paradigmatic of the aggression and lack of protection that the “lords” are willing to go to, for their own benefit. The gentlemen we are talking about, is it economic and political power? The group of political, social, cultural and economic power. The owner, the colonizer. This group has been in power since it instituted the current system of domination. And that only makes sense within the hierarchically stratified sociopolitical model in which we live. Hence the need to put an end to ‘lords’ and establish a new model of society, healthy, free, without hierarchies or strata, whether of race, class or gender. The model in which we live leads the gypsy community (and beyond) to economic exclusion, removing them from access to the consumption of products or excluding them from their production process; political exclusion associated with lack of access to information; to education and consequently the social exclusion seen in the inequality of access to quality community areas such as restaurants, libraries, theater, cinema, concerts, healthcare, etc. How does a gypsy child feel when they realize they are not part of the whole? Children who never see themselves represented, not in films, not in books, not in cartoons, not even in an advertisement eating cereal, for example? Is this a disaster for self-esteem, is it a priori condemnation? That's really the question. Gypsy people are not “excluded from society”, on the contrary, they are included in it. The problem is the existence of what is cynically called 'social exclusion', an Orwellian term, and people are under duress. Which concentration and extermination camp. In fact, the Nazi concentration camps are a more visual embodiment of what is called 'social exclusion' and, as here, they were not an 'excluded' part of Nazi society, but rather its fundamental and characterizing structure. It is a place of violence, where people are kept by violence, dedicated to their extermination, and designed so that few people can leave. And yet they resist. Just like in the Nazi concentration camps. And what you listed as an example of the ‘consequence’ of this ‘exclusion’, is in fact the means by which this exclusion also happens and is maintained. Gypsy people are outside the cinemas, either as consumers or producers (but they go to the cinema). They are outside of school, education and the Academy. Either as ‘users’ or as producers (but they go to school and are at the basis of the construction of knowledge and academic and scientific debates). Even in the attack on the gypsy child's self-confidence, we speak of a mechanism for maintaining this situation. But gypsy people respond very well: with gypsy pride. Another resistance, another aggression. Gypsy people are thus included in society. In a place that belongs to this modern model of society. And they resist and counter the power of domination and insist on being in the city, in the cinema, in the theater, in the Academy, in all spaces. With a lot of struggle and always resisting, but they are there. Social exclusion, more than a “place outside of society”, is part of its social structure. Do you mean to say there is collective resistance? At work, already in a context of absolute precariousness, during the pandemic, gypsy people rolled up their sleeves and once again showed proactivity and creativity in adversity. They learned by watching and doing. And here, it is again women who jump to the front line, show their face, learn to use digital tools with their daughters or sons, and launch themselves into the network. And so they explore online sales as well as app-based work (transport or couriers). In housing, in a pandemic context in which evictions were not stopped – as the law itself should and dictates – residents did not stop organizing and fighting against unfair evictions and demanding dignity in housing; residents associations allied in their action with other housing and anti-racist organizations. It is also worth noting how they reinvented themselves and intensified to collect and distribute food items and mask/alcohol gel kits to the most expropriated people. Gypsies and non-gypsies. In the anti-racist fight, new movements emerged and their actions intensified through social media. People who had never organized or become active before began their first steps in activism, joining this path of gypsy and anti-racist organization and popular action. People forget, or don't want to appreciate, but gypsy action has helped to determine results in the political dispute. Gypsy citizens mobilized in large numbers and determined electoral results in the 2017 local councils, both in Alentejo and in the Lisbon Metropolitan Area, even causing electoral earthquakes. And even in the Presidential elections, second place was decided by an amount equivalent to the estimated number of gypsy voters. Apart from the non-gypsy votes that were mobilized by the action of gypsy voters. Gypsy people are even co-building power in opinion spaces, in local media, on social networks and in party and institutional political disputes. And most importantly, in popular action and in alliances with other social movements. We never stopped fighting by all means and we continued to resist.
